8th Sept 2013, We visited this famous,popular & fantasy figure place.On cloudy day we walked from MRT station all alog the park to the famous MERLION w,national identity of the Singapore with LION head & Fish body.Situated at water front with water coming out from the mouth of the lion is a giant statue in white color.Groups of people were recording their visit by movie & still camera pictures.We also enjoyed our visit by taking pictures & visiting nearby areas.Worth remembering trip.

After a busy day at Marina Bay visiting the museum and sights and a trip on the Singapore Flyer we caught a river taxi over to the Merlion. Heaps of people here taking photos just like us, but such a great atmosphere. After we strolled to the MRT station to catch the train back to our hotel. It is a must visit when in Singapore.

I took my photos with the Merlion here, good when at dusk. Many people are here too. You can see the light exhibits from the Marina Sands Bay in front of it and the Fullerton Hotel at the back of the Merlion.
You must see the Merlion if you come to Singapore - there are always people around but you can get a good photo with Marina Sands in the background.

if you are in Singapore, it wont be a complete visit if you missed the Merlion. well yeah I know its just a Statue and nothing else but the history behind is interesting. What its importance and how come this MErlion is the Icon of Singapore. you take a photo there and enjoy the view. Singapore is very warm and sunny so get hydrated right. there are also shops to eat and drink to replenish. it's for free and there is an MRT just across the bridge.

You have to go here for the photo opportunity. Almost impossible to visit without huge crowds, but that adds to the sense of fun. Always someone willing to take a photo of you and language never seems to be a problem.

THE spot to be photographed while in Singapore. Beautiful bay views and iconic spot to view the metamorphosis that is transforming Singapore into one of the most dynamic, forward-thinking cities on the planet. Have a cocktail at the Fullerton and be happy to be alive. Hordes of people, but who cares? It's kinda what makes it fun. Great place to take a "selfie".

This really is little more than a space around the Merlion - the iconic symbol of modern Singapore. That said there are also great views across the water to Marina Bay and the Theater on the bay. It's a must visit spot not only to see the MerLion statue / fountain but also to get souvenir photographs - it really is the spot to get the Facebook "Im in Singapore" snap ! Can't imagine visiting Singapore and not coming here - Its only a statue / fountain but it is a must see !

Think of the atmosphere of Trafalgar Square in London but with an area on a much smaller scale! A great place to take memorable photos with the statue itself and of the views out to Marina Bay Sands. Lots of locals and tourists create great ambience - then catch the River Taxi across to Marina Bay Shoppes for a memorable night out!

I have heard of this place ever since I was a child. Definitely the most famous landmark of Singapore.  Short walk from downtown or Chinatown, beautiful view at night. Nice night view, skyscraper around, full of tourists. Indeed beautiful, but don't expect it to be super "amazing". After all it is just a statue... even no actual "park" around it.  If you only have couple of hours in Singapore, this is definitely top 1 must go place, but don't expect more than what you see on a picture.

Its just a nice picture spot. Overlooking the lagoon and marina bay sands, pictures like any tourists would. It is nice to walk around a little. I also saw a different view of merlion from the bridge while watching the singapore F1, aside from the bay grandstands.

Since this is probably the most famous landmark of Singapore, visiting it was on the top of our list. This was the first place we visited during our stay here. And we visited it twice, once during the day and once during the night. The best time is at night when you can also enjoy the view of the city, its lights sparkling. The crowd there is also mostly of tourists. It is a place you wouldn’t want to miss.

review_title: A fun place for a memorable photo of Singapore
review_content: The Merlion is seemingly always swimming with tourists and all the package bus tours stop there but if you want a memorable and unique photo of Singapore, you will have to make the pilgrimage as well. I recommend about 15 minutes there and then maybe a stroll along the waterfront. Lots on nice restaurants nearby as well.

review_title: How I knew I was really in Singapore
review_content: There's a replica Merlion in the Southbay in Northern California that we always got a kick out of. So I knew I had to see the real deal when I was actually in Singapore. Best to go in the evening. But overall, just one of those attractions that you go and see, just to say you saw it. :)

Well... there is nothing else other than the statue or the Merlion here, but the view is very nice. You can see the Marina Bay Sands in the background.  Best to visit in the evening since it can be very hot during the day. Bring umbrella or cap!  visits is free of charge, to get there you alight at Raffles Place MRT station on East West Line. Exit towards United Overseas Bank Plaza and from the middle of the plaza, you'll see the Fullerton Hotel. Merlion Park is just right behind it.

review_title: Nice Place to Visit at Night
review_content: One of those places you will go visit just because it's a popular landmark. Nothing much to do here but take a picture or maybe stay awhile adoring the view and cool breeze from the bay.

Best place to go during the night. Merlion looks beautiful with the Fullerton hotel at the background and facing the Marina Bay sands. Best place to sit and watch the wonder full light and water show. Singapore river in the front gives a good back drop.Good place to take snaps.The Singapore River ferry starts from here too and lot of eateries are available.

The word Singapore originated from a lots of names before. As i I rememberd when the prince of the country saw a lion, he took this as an auspicious sign and founded a settlement called Singapura, which means "Lion City". And now it is Singapore. You will not be in Singapore once you don't pay a visit to the symbol of this city: Merlion park. This should be a must-be attraction in Singapore and a famous landmark. Don't forget the coffee and snack beside. It won't let you down. If you have time, come to this place at night. Its blazer at night is a speculation. Come here and take photo. You are in Singapore.

review_title: Grab your icecream and sit here
review_content: I bought frostbite ice cream by the statue and sat there enjoyed the afternoon breeze. The statue was surrounded by tourists taking photos. You can take river cruise from here too.

review_title: One of the three most disappointed sight-seeing spot in the world
review_content: One of the three most disappointed sight-seeing spot in the world!, Opera House in Sydney, Den lille havfrue in Copenhagen,  AND MERLION IN SINGAPORE!   Many and many and many people to take photo! crowd I was tired of it.

This is the most famous cityscape of Singapore.  I was in Singapore just for a few hours between connections flights, but the sufficient time to visit the city center and this was the destination I have choosed.  This is like Big Ben in London, it´s a "must see", there´s always hundreds of people there thousands of pictures taken. The Lion, the big hotel and a lot of more attractions possible to see from this point
It was a nice to see that beautiful attraction at the Marina bay...will visit again in the future for sure
This is great place to take photo memorabilia...It symbolizes the greatness and the uniqueness of this country!

Take a taxi or MRT to the Marina to see the Merlion. Walk up close for your pictures - you'll get sprayed, but it will cool you down! The bay is a beautiful place to walk around and you will find open restaurants for lunch or a drink. This area is walkable to other attractions, including Raffles Hotel and WWII monument.
It's a lovely place and a great spot. Do not miss having snack or coffee beside the area.This place was by far the best i encountered in our 3day stay. We had a nice time.

I was actually there with my Japanese friend, as she requested me to bring her there. We went there at night, and the MBS laser show was indeed spectacular. My friend was really amused as she thought that it was a great difference as seen in the day as compared to enjoying the view at night. As for me, it's still alright, since I'm a Singaporean and had seen this multiple times. It's not something special to me. Hence, I would think that, this attraction probably appeals more to the tourists. And I must say, that area is pretty touristy though.   I highly recommend to go there when it's night, as the lighting at night really enhances the whole experience.

It was Fantastic! We visited it in the night. In the night only it is more beautiful. When you enter be careful for you might totally get wet. Life time memories were created. You can see a good view of many Landmarks of Singapore!

review_title: Good place to stroll and catch MBS laser show!!
review_content: Its a nice premonade to just walk around or grab a cuppa coffee or some drinks around this area at open air cafes.. Its equally refreshing if you stroll around this windy area in the evening and enjoy the closer view of cbd and the MBS.. Dont forget to catch the evening Marina Bay Sands lazer light Show for free.. This park gives an awesome view of this show.. It also happens around 9:15 pm as well.. goes about for 10 mins.. Nice place to be around 7-8 pm, especially after sunset..

Although there were many tourists there, we still had a nice time. A bit difficult to find, nevertheless we took lots of photos and took a boat trip down the river to Clarke Quay. Well worth the visit.
A good photo opportunity...the fullerton is beside it and is a lovely property. Grab an ice lolly and take as many snaps as you can with beautiful views of the Bay

One of the most visited attraction in Singapore. Regardless of the hot humid weather and the crowd, tourists battle to get a good spot of taking a perfect photo of the statue of the MERLION, and I was one of them. This statue, sprouts an endless jet of water from its jaws. The area overlooks the Marina bay which is really a nice view of the water and the high rise of Marina Sands Skypark. I saw the crowd here during night and day and it never ceased.

The icon for the lion city Singapore. Overlooking the Marina Bay sands hotel and the marina bay. restaurants and coffee shops are available at this location and is recommended for solo or family travel

The Iconic statue of Merlion ,part Fish and part Lion is the national symbol of Singapore.This place is the Merlion's den ,and visit to the statue is a must for tourists.Nice scenery ,overlooking the Marina Bay ,can see the Marina Bay Shopping Complex , the Esplanade ,and view of the Singapore River.Go early in the morning to avoid the crowd of go in the afternoon to see the stunning lighting of the surrounding buldings , u can watch the symhony of lights also from here

This palace is very famous to all the visitor of this rich city state in south east Asia,almost every tourist wants to have a photo off with on this park, the Merlion is Singapore most beloved and Famous icon,I'm not amazed why every tourist wants to have a picture with him. You could reach this via the underground train system of Singapore alight at raffles station,on this area you could see a lot of things like the Marina bay sands hotel and the Singapore flyer to name a few.

review_title: Super touristy with most tourists posing in a unique manner.
review_content: No idea why all the tour groups seem to like this place as a gathering spot. Many many tourists flooding this area and cluttering to pose with their mouths open, seemingly to drink water from the Merlion's spout. Sadly, it becomes more annoying than anything.  Only expensive places to eat around here. The only good thing about being here is the vantage point of MBS.

Decided to walk round all of Marina Bay, Merlion Park is part of the walk , it is located close to the opera house. The park has great views of the Marina Bay Sands and has a large water side statue. The downside is that this area is the busiest area around the bay with coach loads of tourists flocking to take pictures.

review_title: Must Visit if near to it
review_content: Good place to hang out, & symbol to be in Singapore,  Do try Coffee & cool Breeze at Starbucks Coffee Shop.
Nice for that Iconic views and photographs of Singapore (eg. Merlion and Marina Bay Sands Hotel) to add to your album. A must visit for the first timer.

review_title: Important landmark and thus important ... Nothing special though !!!
review_content: Anyone who Visits Singapore needs to have a picture near the MerLion to complete the trip pictorially. Australia has the Opera House an SG has its Merlion as the Landmark.  So me n wife reached to complete SG trip by having a picture here. I visited twice - Once in the night and once in the day. I have to say that I Liked the place more in the night. The Fullerton Hotel looked more beautiful n so did the Merlion with the water oozing

This is a must visit place as it ensures you are in Singapore. Lots of People taking photos in front of the Merlion who is throwing water from the mouth. Best view in the back as lots of Hi Rise building of offices, banks are around. It is close to Fullerton Hotel.  Get down at Raffles Place MRT Station & walk for 10 min to reach there.

This is the most iconic of Singapore. The origin place of the Merlion is here. Used to have a street/road called Elizabeth Walk and it has since made way for the flashy Fullerton Hotel and other eateries.

We went to Merlion Park on our way out from Sentosa Island. We’ve passed by it three times because at first we did not know that we are supposed to get off the bus at Resorts World to go to the aquarium. I could read English signs but there was not a single one in sight or direction to be found that we need to get off at Resorts World in order to go to the aquarium. When the bus passed by the Merlion once more we realized that we just turned around and going back to where we came from. The driver announced that he reach the end of the line and stopping for some time. We told him that we are going to the aquarium, "that was in Resorts World", he replied. We did not see any signs or hear any announcement in the bus.....I was upset and got off and make our way to board another bus. The driver followed us and explained....I told him that it does not make sense, we’ve been to a lot bigger amusement parks like Universal in Hollywood, Disney World in Florida and Disneyland in Anaheim....and we never get lost....why here? Tourist area like this are frequently visited by from out of town/country travelers, not locals. Directions and communications are very essential if not important.
I was really sad because I can not take any good pictures. It was rain in the afternoon. From this area we can see view of esplanade, marina bay sand and singapore flier.

review_title: Do not forget this on your itinerary
review_content: The place is very popular for tourists/travelers, Its nice that they have this place so tourists can visit and relax. You will never get tired of taking beautiful pictures if you visit this awesome place! The view is superb.

review_title: Nice place to make pictures (fantastic view)
review_content: Merlion Park is located at One Fullerton, Singapore near the Central Business District (CBD) area of Singapore. This park is a popular tourist attraction. There are two structures of the Merlion located at the park with one standing at 8.6 metres which is the original Merlion statue and a 2-metre tall Merlion cub located just behind the original statue. The park is also a major tourist attraction and a landmark of Singapore.  To access take Exit A from Raffles Place MRT Station and walk towards the waterfront

I went here only because it is considered the icon of Singapore! Nothing special except for the merlion. Although the surrounding view is quite good but it is a norm regarding a whole lot of other artificial feats in Singapore so I was not so much impressive! A pose with the merlion is enough. If your budget allows, you could also hop onto a cruise to see some famous sites around the bay. The price is more or less 30 SD.

One of 5 Merlions in Singapore, Merlion Park is worth a quick visit to see, have your picture taken and more so, take in the greats views from this location. Make sure spend some time here taking some pictures looking out from the Merlion and you'll come away with a number of great shots. The evening is a good time to visit as well in order to view the Marina Bay Sands laser show.

The night lights are a great view at the Merlion Park. There are plenty to see here -- from the Merlion, the symbol of Singapore, to the historic Fullerton Hotel, to the Singapore skyscrapers, to the Marina Bay Sands, to the Singapore Flyer, to the Esplanade -- you'll find a great feast to the eyes 360 degrees.  You can get to Merlion Park by getting the MRT to the Esplanade. It is a nice spot to watch the boats from the river going towards Marina Bay.

review_title: A historical symbol not to be mised.
review_content: We went to visit the Merlion park in the evening time. It was beautiful and had magnificent views. Especially when the evening sun hitting the Marina Bay Sands, the outcome of the photos you take are awesome. This is a historical symbol that has been a must see monument for every visitor to Singapore. The whole surroundings of this Merlion park are very fun place to chill for few hours. Very nice views of the skyline of Singapore and water. A must see place for all the visitors to Singapore.
Nice place to see. The merlion is excellent view. crowds also manageable. lovely view form far and near. all in all an excellent place.

I am sad that Singapore has let their tourism symbol become a dirty and ugly statue. What's there to see? Nothing but a statue in a very poor condition.I could see the disappointment on others' too.  Well, if it's the first time you're I Singapore, come to see it once, then I think it's quite enough because you won't want to come back. You can reach it not too difficultly by MRT (North south line, City Hall station leading directly to inside Esplanade theater, take the lift there from b1 up to ground floor, walk out of the theater from the main gate, you'll see the bridge connecting the theater with Fullerton hotel and the Merlion, take a walk, 7 minutes, very beautiful view!)

No visit to Singapore would be complete without having a picture taken with the at the Merlion. very crowded in the evening though, but you shouldn't miss the photo op. Also good shots of marina bay sands and Merlion together to get a souviner of your visit. Loved it.

I think for lot of people visit Singapore will regret if without visit to Merlion Park for the symbolic Lion Head fish body sculpture landmark - Merlion.  Here actually got two, one original one, located here and one giant size one located at Santosa island.  When you are here, you can one shot get the new modern landmark Sands Marina Bays as the nice background.

review_title: Excellent shots too of Marina Bay Sands and the Singapore Flyer
review_content: No visit to Singapore would be complete without a photo at the Merlion Park. Lots of people, though, but you shouldn't miss having your photo taken here. Excellent shots too of Marina Bay Sands and the Singapore Flyer.
one of the place that have to visit in singapore. cos it's merlion, icon of singapore. so can't miss it if that is the first time go to singapore
Had a great time at the Merlion and the rest of the beautiful places in Singapore. I want to visit again with my family next time.
One of the well-known places in Singapore, the park was nice to visit. We had great time viewing the Merlion and clicking pictures around that place.
Had a great time at the Merlion. Kids loved the whole story-telling aspect, with putting the gold coin into the machine to get a prize. View from the head and mouth is awesome. Good value for money.
Its like everyone should be here. a little too crowd and get the best moment at night. It was so hot in here and i think they have to create a green space in there.

review_title: Nothing at all...but isn't it nice to have a green space in the city?
review_content: Good: -Nice for a 5 minute walk. -Nice metal sculpture. -Nice flowers.  Bad: -No shade for people to rest in the park. -Limited F&B outlets. -Involves walking to this place.

I loved hanging out at this park. It was best at night to watch the lightshow across the water at Marina Bay Sands. It's probably one of the few places in Singapore where the food options are a little lacking. Otherwise it's a great place.
If you use MRT, you can go to MRT EW Raffles place, then you exit H (battery road). You will see a nice view, near the river.
Busy area , but a compulsory to take foto in here. Many Indonesian here and asian , several coffee shops available and also souvenir shop.  Its hot when I was there.

The greatest historical landmark of Singapore; the gateway to touristy Singapore! A great place to spend time solo or with family/ friends. Take lots of photographs or just sit near the Lionhead and admire the beautiful skyline of Singapore. You can see the Marina Bay Snads on the other side of the water and the Giant Wheel of the Esplanade. The river front is also attractive with some ferry rides. Nearby are some restaurants and also a washroom facility, should you need. Easily accessible from the Raffles Place MRT stattion.

review_title: Take your photo and move on
review_content: Not much to do here, but it's one if those "must visits" to see official Merlions and take the requisite tourist photo. Beyond that, it wasn't really all that interesting. Lots of people made it difficult to get a photo, so be patient and have your trigger finger ready! You have to be quick to get a shot before another tourist enters the scene.
a must when going to singapore theres coffee shops and resturants along the pier its a beautiful statue great for photos

review_title: The place to take your "I went to Singapore" photo
review_content: Very well maintained promenade leading to the Merlion statue. It's pretty packed with people taking pictures with the statue as a backdrop. You can also get some cool pictures with Marina Bay Sands and the Artscience Museum in the backdrop.  I would caution people against leaning on the railings, everyone seems to do it and the railing seems a bit strained.
This was my 2nd time to see the Merlion but my 1st time to go at night. In my opinion it is better at night because of the lighting the Merlion really pops out. The view there is just spectacular.

Not quite the experience we thought of, with the 'park' effectively being a bit of a pier??  the stature itself is pretty cool, and there were lots of tourists taking pics etc.  It's prob best seen at night from a boat, with the marina lit up  Worth seeing, but not worth a special trip to see  that said, cracking view of the surrounding buildings from the end of the pier

Part of our city tour was the visit in Merlion park where you can see the lion headed fish statue, which we always see on post cards or fliers advertising Singapore. Nothing special but a good place to take photos. The ocean view is quite nice.
This is a well-known tourist icon of singapore. Speciality is that,the Merlion statue has a lion's head and a fish's body.This park is a popular tourist attraction.

review_title: Your photo will scream "I went to Singapore"
review_content: This is a place you will go to take a picture that overflows with the message "I went to Singapore," but that's about it. Nice view of that giant hotel across the water (if you care to see it), and a nice view of the downtown district.  In terms of things to actually do there...that would be approximately take a picture and leave. It's not a bad place, but there isn't anything to do except take a picture. Very touristy, tons of people in the afternoon. That's about it.
singapore's tourist spot indeed! lots of tourists around the area. good for taking pictures gives you a great view of the sea. i recommend you come here at night. less people and amazing night view.

Having no context for this statue I'm unable to appreciate it. It just looks silly. More silly yet are throngs of tourists having their pics taken in front of it.  There is however a great view from this park of a triple tower building with a massive canoe-like structure on top.
We thought it would be a Great Big Statue but it was not quite that. We found the Merlion at Sentosa is better

It will not complete if we don't come to Merlion Park during our days in Singapore. This is the symbol of Singapore. The view is very interesting. And again, i recommend you to come at night. The night view is amazing. Again and again, romantic place :) :) I really enjoyed the view at night. I'll come there again :):)

The Merlion statue in this park has the head of a Lion and the body of a fish with water gushing out of the mouth. Almost all tourists to Singapore come to this place which is an icon of Singapore. A statue of a baby Merlion is also located nearby.From here the views of the Singapore Flyer, and the Marina Bay sands hotel building are captivating. The place is a bit crowded but still worth a visit.

We were just lucky to come here on a weekday and a gloomy weather so basically we truly did enjoy the view & museum on our way. There are also restaurants and starbucks chain available few steps to the park.   The view of the Marina Bay Sands, Singapore Flyer and the Park was gorgeous.
merlion is the icon of singapore. when you come to singapore, you must visit this merlion park. You must have your own picture at the lion statue.

As I had time left, I visited this iconic landmark like many, many others. The view is quite spectacular, due to the combination of the statue, wheel and the amazing hotel at the other side of the water. As there were crowds of people, it was quite difficult to make a nice picture of the Merlion without tourists. During the day it is not really worth the visit, but in the evening the pictures are awesome. So make sure to come early in the evening in order not to miss the sunset.
It's a nice place to visit. Merlion park is the sympol of Singapore. You can take a boat to go round the bay and take some photos. There are lots of view for you to capture.

review_title: Singapore means Merlion hence must watch
review_content: This structure represents Singapore so no one should miss this.  Structure is unique, place around this is superb which means tourists would get so many scene to capture and make nice memory.  Few pubs and bars are also available but its quite expense.  Best option is go Clarke Quay and then take boat (river ride) and get down to Merlion to capture the memorable moments.  Second best option from Clarke Quay just can walk upto Merlion, it would take 20 mins walk but in between you will get few more structure and ice cream vendor.

review_title: Good views from a boat trip
review_content: Take a boat trip round the bay and you get excellent views & photo opportunities of the Merlion without the crowds. Like a previous reviewer said, it's not overwhelming, but it is a landmark monument.

Worth it just because this is the monument that represents the city, and it is the most renowned landmark. If you don't get to make it to the Merlion during your visit though, you're not missing anything that would have made a great memory.
Iconic land mark of singapore that you've to take the picture. Very crowd. But what can I say? I had to bring home my picture at merlion as proof that i've visited singapore.
Great view and excellent service, but the best part was watching a short and entertaining movie to learn about the history of Singapore

The merlion is a signature image of Singapore, and this park is a must see place in Singapore. Visiting Singapore is not complete before visiting Merlion Park. This is a place with an excellent view to take photographs, even if you don't always take yourself within those photos.

Merlion is the well known as the symbol of Singapore, that's why every person go to Singapore must go there. From Merlion park we can see Singapore flyer, Esplanade, One fullerton, and Marina bay sands

review_title: Singapore landmark overrun bus bus loads of tourists
review_content: Located in the center of the business district at the waters edge, the Merlion is worth a look. Huge crowds diminish the experience somewhat, but other attractions are within strolling range, and the spot offers nice views across the water. Nearby at the sea wall, bum boats offer sightseeing tours along the Singapore River, and the venerable Fullerton Hotel is just a short walk along the shore away.
Merlion the Icon of Singapore and is surrounded by the the Raffles place,Singapore Flyer,Marina Bay sands etc....what a place --worth to visit.
user_location: National Capital Territory of Delhi, India

review_title: Small park but that's the Merlion matters!!
review_content: Actually, the park is really small!! I think it just consists of a giant Merlion and a small merlion statue and nothing more. However, you may find a good view for taking a picture that capture Merlion statue and Marina bay sand together!!   I went there by taking the SMRT to Raffle places, and walking along to Fullerton area. Just find some sunny afternoon and take a walk here!

The Merlion is Singapore's Icon with great significant. Standing so proudly facing Marina bay city. Which once upon a time was a sea. Merlion park a cool place to be for family photograph and traveller's memory.

The merlion is a signature image of Singapore, and this park is a must see place in Singapore. Located in the center of business district, it is very convenient to reach there by mrt train, bus or taxi. We took taxi and got there very fast from Chinatown. From the park, you can see all the famous attractions such as Esplanade Theater, Marina Bay Sands, Raffles statue...in walking distance. The merlion is a combination of the lion in the upper body and the fish tail in the lower body. The park stays near the water, and tons of water come out from the the mouth of the merlion. This place sometimes is cramped and difficult to take photos. Avoid going there in the sunny time also, it burned you down very fast.
A must to see as it's a big part of Singapore. Busy in the evening with lots of people taking pictures and hanging out by the sea.

MERLION PARK is situated at 1, Fullerton Singapore, near Esplanade Bridge. You will find here famous and popular statues of the Merlion and a Merlion cub. They were originally located at the mouth of the Singapore River, but now they have been shifted here from the year 2002.The Merlion is a Singapore tourism symbol.  From this park, you can approach nearby attractions like famous Singapore flyer, Art Science Museum, Asian Civilization Museum, Esplanade Park, Esplanade - Theaters on the Bay, Marina Bay City Gallery, Marina Bay Sands Skating Rink, Marina Bay Waterfront Promenade, Mist Walk, National Art Gallery, Sand sky Park, The Arts House, The Float @ Marina Bay, The Fullerton Heritage Gallery, The Helix, Victoria Theater and Victoria Concert Hall. A good place to eat, drink, walk around and spend nice evening.
Just a place to take a few photographs on the way to somewhere else. Take the piccies and then to Lau Pa Sat for lunch!

review_title: Extremely crowded, but worth a visit at least once
review_content: The Merlion is a Singapore mascot and a mythical creature with the head of a lion & body of a fish. The lion head represents Singapore's origins to be a "lion city" {it's said that the first beast the person who founded Singapore saw was a lion, hence the name} and the fish body was because Singapore used to be a fishing village.  The Merlion Park actually has 2 Merlion structures, the original Merlion statue {8.6m} sprouting water into the Singapore River, and a cute baby Merlion cub {2m}. There's a few nice cafes around, and it's walking distance from other famous places of interest like the Padang, St Andrew's Cathedral and Raffles City. There's also a souvenir shop nearby but unless you want to be ripped off, I don't recommend you buying any omiyage from there. I had a look and a miniature wooden Merlion costs S$68!   It really was so packed over the weekend so if you do want to visit and get nice photographs, try to go over the weekdays. There's still space for kids to run around and have fun though.  There's actually 5 official Merlion statues in Singapore! One at Sentosa Island, two at Merlion Park, one more at Tourism Court {near Grange Road} and another at Mount Faber.   You can see my photos here: http://www.sakuraharuka.com/2013/04/bub-me-mighty-singapore-merlion.html
Merlion isn't overly exciting just something u check out, but the surrounding area is amazing to walk around,

This is just a statue of the merlion....the one on Sentosa is more impressive in terms of size. This one I found hard to get to (we were on foot & had to cross several busy roads). I think it would be nicer to see from a river cruise...
Even if this place is one of the more touristic in Singapour i can only recommand you to visit it. Night view is spectacular and it-s a great opportunity for photos (even fun one)

Who doesn't recognize the image of the Merlion and associate it with the great city of Singapore?  We remember not too many years back when standing near the Merlion statue, you would be looking into a nice but empty Bay only able to see the reclaimed but undeveloped land known as Marina South. Just a few years later, the Merlion now faces the futuristic Marina Bay Sands Hotel (MBS), ArtScience Museum, Helix Bridge and the glowing Supertrees of the Gardens by the Bay just behind MBS. What a brave new world standing before the Merlion these days.   The Merlion is slowly losing its place as the face of Singapore as more people begin to associate the creative architectural developments like MBS with the city. This old symbol of the Singapore is now just one of many things to see in the Marina Bay area, representing its past while the rest of the city moves full steam ahead into the future.   We like the Merlion and are glad that it has maintained its foothold in the exciting new environment found around Marina Bay. It is a part of Singapore's past and heritage and is worth discovering for visitors of the city.   You can find the Merlion Statue just in front of the One Fullerton Heritage shopping and dining facility along the waterfront, facing the Marina Bay Sands.

review_title: Go There Early if You Want to Avoid Too Many Toursits
review_content: The place is rather small and usually always packed with tourists taking picture of this formerly iconic statue of Singapore. There is a great view of the financial / business district just behind the Lion, and this is definitely worth a few pictures, for which you will have to be patient if you want a tourist-free shot.

Merlion is the well known as the symbol of Singapore, that's why every person go to Singapore must go there. This "lion fish " statue attracts tourists from around the world. From Merlion park we can see Singapore flyer, Esplanade, One fullerton, and Marina bay sands. You can sit here and enjoy the activity in Singapore river. Best time to go there is in the afternoon, because the lights from many buildings and from Merlion statue itself is awesome. From Raffles place MRT station just take about 15 minutes to go there. But you must cross the road by underpass.
This small park is refreshing, clean, and has a relaxing atmosphere which is wonderful especially for those who just want to sit and watch the happenings on the bay with a coffee

From this spot It's a great point of view of Singapore Wharf, have been there in the evening as during the day and I have to admit that in both cases was always full of tourists even difficult to take pictures. Apart from all this influx of people the place is great, I enjoyed a beautiful view and the evening with hundreds of lights and colors, the atmosphere is surreal. The big statue of half lion and half fish is unquestionably one of the symbols of the city, this is a big fountain gushing water all the time. It is a must for those tourists who stay in Singapore for a short time.
but dwarfed by all the other things around Marina Bay. Crowded with tourists when we went, so hard to enjoy.
A must visit place in Singapore is the Merlion Park: half lion and half fish statue. This is also the landmark of Singapore.

Really awed by the view of this park! From here you could see Marina Bay Sands, the Singapore Flyer, the Esplanade Theatre. You could also sit in some benches if you want to savor the view. I recommend you to go here before sunset until the night time falls, to experience both effects of day time and night time!

review_title: A good place to relax for a while
review_content: We went here, morning time. Took a bus with a short 3 stops from our hotel and walk through the boardwalk from Fullerton Hotel.  It's a nice open space with the Merlion statue spitting water :) and attracts our son. The marina view is always cool to see.   There is a river cruise booth nearby, which we did not take, and prefer the $3 bubblejet boat taxi for a one-way trip to CQ.  Nearby of merlion there are several sightseeing spots to lookout and only within walking distance such as Cavenagh Bridge, Raffless Landing Spot, also stroll along the riverside and you will end up at the Helix Bridge
This is become the icon of Singapore. It is not complete to visit this country without visit this statue. It's free. It's easy to get to this park. The easiest way is by taking the MRT.
nice place to be visited...one of the most interesting place in singapore. its free and beautiful place
I really love the wind there. It's super nice that you just sit there and enjoy the view. I really love it that there are coffee shops too.

review_title: Must see for the first timers
review_content: 1. This is one of the few attractions of singapore which is completely free and it is the symbol of singapore, so every first traveller to singapore must visit it! 2. Very good photo oppurtunities with the lion and also the singapore skyline 3. Around certain times( one being 9:30) there is laser show from skypark at the other side of bay. You will have the best views of the show from here 4. Res and cafe like coffee bean tea leaf and starbucks are available in the park area

It is interesting just to go here and watch people. This icon is newly refurbished and still the king of icons in Singapore. Worth the time to see. In fact just to stand here and look all around is worth while. People know you're in Singapore when you have your photo taken here.

What else but a picture with Singapore's well known landmark. Best to go late in the afternoon to avoid the intense heat of the sun and to appreciate the night lights. Stay for a while longer to watch the light show at Marina Bay.

review_title: The most important part: It's FREE!
review_content: We went to the Merlion Park late morning / nearing noon I think. So it was really really hot! We wanted to do all the touristy stuff and had enjoyed the view from Merlion Park immensely. Place was packed with other tourists as well, so please be advised to play nice and make sure to take turns posing with the Merlion statue. And for crying out loud, please do not photobomb. Some people don't appreciate it.  We were there for only 15-20 minutes. Must go. Why wouldn't you, when it's free?
Short walk from Boat Quay via Fulleton Hotel underpass. Great view of Marina Bay Sands. Good cafes and restaurants around. One can take water taxi from there to ho to Clarke Quay.

review_title: Can't say you have visited Singapore ....
review_content: until you have seen Merlion. Good to come in the evening and watch the sun go down. Mingle with tourist and local alight. Must go and free!

Merlion is something what Singapore represents for tourists. So it is worth to visit if you are the first time visitor to Singapore. Merlion itself is ok for me, but I liked the area. Visited at night time.  Along riverside, view of the other side buildings are beautiful. Many restaurants to choose from.

review_title: no point in visiting this extremely touristy "park"
review_content: I really never have seen the point of this park. I been to Singapore twice, and the one time I've been to the Merlion, after three minutes, I had no idea why I was even there. This seemed like the most touristy in all of Singapore, and I seriously don't know why. It's a statue that puts spews water into the bay. That's it. There's no infrastructure or park or anything like that that would make this a destination.   Also, it was mobbed -- absolutely mobbed -- with people taking pictures and posing for pictures ...and all I wanted to do was get out of there as soon as possible. You can walk around the bay and see the Merlion, and figure out for yourself it's worth walking all the way over there in a mob of tourists to take a picture.  Absolutely not recommended.

The Merlion is a fun and unique monument. From the esplanade you have amazing views of Marina Bay and Marina Bay Sands. Although crowded, it's still really cool. We walked from Clarke Quay through Merlion Park past the Fullerton Hotel then onto Marina Bay.

A short walk from Raffles mrt via Fullerton. A very nice spot for picture taking. A photo mark that you have been to Singapore. Shops are located near the site but clustered on a way for tourist to enjoy the view. Btw, there is an ice cream man just across esplanade bridge that sells ice cream (what else) for SGD 1.

review_title: A Photography Hot Spot for all Visitors
review_content: The Merlion Symbol was created in year 1964 as the logo for the Singapore Tourism Board. Featuring a Lion’s Head and a Fish Body, the Sculpture of this Mythical Creature was first located at the mouth of the Singapore River in September 1972 but after the construction of the Esplanade Bridge, the view of the Merlion was blocked and it was relocated to its’ present location at the Merlion Park in April 2002, overlooking the Marina Bay.  Over the years, the Merlion has become the Iconic Symbol of Singapore and the current Merlion Park is a Photography Hot Spot for all visitors to Singapore as it features the Majestic Merlion set in the beautiful New Skyline of the Marina Bay area. Almost all visitors to Singapore would like to have a photograph taken with the Merlion in various posts for their album.   The Merlion is a very Photogenic Creature and it always turn up well in photographs, be it in the morning, afternoon or night depending on the preference of the individual. For me, I like it best when it was painted in Multi-colours by the ingenious lighting effect during the iLight Marina Bay 2012 Light Festival.

This place is always packed with tourist, morning, noon or night. If you want to take a lot of pictures from lots of angles u better starts from the morning and not on the weekends.  Once u r here take the time to also enjoy the marvelous Marina bay sands building and also the Fullerton hotel. If u need some refreshment there are also available such as starbucks, stomping ground, and some other beer stops.  If u want u also can use Singapore river cruise that will take u across or have a tour in the river.
I like the Merlion, but was disappointed (as were the kids) that most of it was not operating and was under repair. Also not friendly for prams.

Singapore = Merlion, so for a first timer, go there. Even, you can have a great view from their surrounding, the new famous marina bay sand, the Singapore flyer, and the esplanade theater. You can reach there easily by bus. They have 2 statue, the Big one which spurt the water, and the small one (which i don't know what good about it; or maybe it's because it is under maintenance. Remember to bring your own water bottle, since they charge you double on every water and food sold there. And not to forget, go there at night to make it even more beautiful of light show there.

I visited this attraction on a Sunday late morning in February 2013. The place is so packed with tourists taking pictures from every angles. With the new Marina Bay Sands completed in a distant, now Merlion does not facing the open sea anymore, but towards the big "lake" which is surrounded by buildings around.  Still free of charge, the ground is kept immaculately clean. A Singapore river cruise counter is located nearby with a small jetty. I actually wished to try the water taxi ride from Merlion jetty to Marina Bay Sands (bayfront jetty), but was told the waiting time is approx 20-30mins which is rather long.  Restaurants and coffee shops can be found around the area, including the one at One Fullerton.  Best time to visit: with the crowd around, come early in the morning or late in the evening Best access: if you're on your own, take the underpass through Fullerton Hotel or you can take a leisure stroll along Nicoll Highway from Esplanade - theatres by the bay.

there a sudden burst of rain and as expected, pathways will be dirty and slippery but to my surprise, there were aides who in a nick of time cleared up the streets and passages to the Merlion became safe.

Merlion can be seen just opposite to marina bay sands. It is complete visiting to Singapore without visiting Merlion. Its a head of a Lion and body Of a Mermaid (fish). nice place to stand and walk around along the riverside. Have a few riveerside cafe nearby. woth visiting. beautifully made.
Make sure you get a picture here. Better in the afternoon, before sunset you'll get the best pic. Gets too crowded in public holidays.

You shouldn't miss having your photo taken with the Merlion :) The Icon of Singapore. Try to go early to avoid the crowd. We got off at the Esplanade MRT and walked at the side of Esplanade. Great view of Marina Bay Sands & the Singapore Flyer.

Like the Colloseum, Eiffel tower, and the Leaning Tower, this Merlion Park is a tourist trap. The place itself is decent, clean with several cafes to relax. But aside from the Merlion, there's really nothing else to see here.

Visiting Singapore is not complete before visiting Merlion Park. This is a place with an excellent view to take photographs, even if you don't always take yourself within those photos. The riverside café nearby also delivers good view. The little Merlion statue is also a fun place to take photos. And the best of all is that there is no entrance fee or something. The only things that denied me to give 5 stars: If there are too many people, it will be difficult for you to get a solo photograph.
Had been here once , found it nice ... just stroll around and take pics , apart from that der isnt much to bragg about this place .

review_title: Great view of the Marina Bay Sands
review_content: Lovely view of the new Marina Bay Sands and you can take a picture with the Singapore icon, the Merlion (A lion with a fish body).

We visited the Merlion during the free tour from Changi Airport. Such a cool statue. Great place to see the city. Awesome view of the Marina Bay and Singapore flyer. Easy to get great shot even with a crowd.

When in Singapore, you have to visit Merlion Park to see the Merlion statute fountain. The statute is on a promenade on Marina Bay and affords great views of Marina Bay, the Marina Bay Sands, the Singapore Flyer, and the Central Business District. There is a little pier that you can walk out on and see the statute from the water. You can also get a good view of the statute from a bum boat which you can catch by Clarke Quay down the Singapore River. Also worth checking out while you are in the area is the Fullerton Hotel which used to be the Singapore Post Office. A little out of the way, but if you take the MRT to Raffles Place it is a short walk to the Fullerton Hotel. From the Fullerton, there is an underground passageway which will take you right to the waterfront and the park. The park is also a nice place to hang, as there are some waterfront cafes and the ubiquitous Starbucks there.

Its a must watch place in Singapre...The Iconic Merlion oversees the Marina bay sands, the Singapore Flyer & is a good photostop destination...1 might wanna carry an umbrella as it can get quite hot over here during the day-time.
Visiting this place at night is way better than during the day. Not only do you get to see with different hues but you get to see/meet some cool singaporeans hanging out as well

Of course no visit to Singapore is complete without seeing the famous Merlion so this location provides just that. We were taken here by a local so getting here was pretty easy. The place is pretty beautiful in the night with lots of great backgrounds to choose from - whether it be the illuminated water, Marina Bay Sands hotel (with it`s awesome architecture) or the Merlion. The area was lively and there are lots of stands nearby to buy food/snacks and souvenirs.

I'm staying in Singapore as an exchange student, and the Merlion Park is one of the places in the city that I'm always happy to visit! While the Merlion Park and Marina Bay Sands right across the water both look gorgeous under daylight, the best time to visit is after dark when the night falls! This is one of the legendary places to take photos of the lovely skyline of Singapore (see photo), and a GREAT place to watch the spotlights-show exhibited by the Marina Bay Sands Hotel right across the harbour from the park!  If you want to visit Merlion Park, I would strongly recommend you to visit when the Marina Bay Sands light show is on. And for your comfort and convenience, here are the times when the spotlights illuminate the gorgeous casino and the entire bay: 8pm, 9:30pm and 11pm! (See photo)
A bit difficult to get here, but it's a must to Come here and took pictures. In here you got to see the lion, Marina bay and Esplanade. One location but lots of beautiful background

review_title: Nice tour and walking around in Merlion Park
review_content: The place is nice for an hour walk and different lookout spots. It is one of the popular tourist spot and we took a walk thru to our hotel in Clark Quay for about 30 minutes. Apart from the warm weather, this is a place you can have a nice and comfort tour, ez walking. The ice cream will help cool you down!

The area is definitely a must-visit tourist attraction. I don't think any first-timer in Singapore would miss taking pictures with the Merlion. Plus, you can get nice photos of the Marina Bay Sands Hotel and other well-known buildings from here. I actually had better views of the city from the Merlion Park, than from the Singapore Flyer - considering the former is free and the latter costs S$30!

review_title: Because you need to be creative
review_content: Like millions of other snappy happy photographers, the Marina Bay Sands picture appear incomplete without Singapore's favorite 'fishnimal' spouting pee from its mouth.

The area ensconed on banks of singapore river is a tourist's delight, if you happen to go to Singapore, the ideal time to visit Merlion Park is evening around 5pm - crowd begin to swell up, lights come on & a microcosm of world can be seen. As you go down the steps and sit on one of those steps clicking pictures of the landscape of Singapore with the Merlion, it becomes an ideal time to pass the evening even if you are alone.The place becomes even more breathtaking as it turns darker.   the historic Fullerton Hotel giving a spectacular view is another sight seeing marvel; don't miss the 'chocolate buffet' that the Fullerton Hotel offers on weekends  The area around the Merlion facing the Anderson bridge is picturesque and you see tourists across the world clicking pictures and taking videos with their families.   One must try the local cuisine restaurants for 'Kopi' , 'Kaya' and 'Laksa' that are typical of Singapore. With live musicians playing music and performing by the banks of the river and water flowing out from the Merlion, you don't realise how hours skip away.

It was a nice sightseeing experience in the so-called Merlion Park along with the great view of Singapore flyer and Marina Bay Sand. The tour guide said that the Merlion Statue there was the first and original statue in Singapore. On the other side of the park, One Fullerton Hotel is situated, wherein the great architecture attracts the tourist too... I really enjoyed this place..

If you're in Singapore and have not paid a visit to this place, then you cannot consider yourself as having been to Singapore. The park, which is home to Merlion a half-fish half-lion creature, symbolise Singapore's great achievements just under 50 years.  If you're visiting the park during a sunny day, do bring along an umbrella as it can get very hot under the sun. You can also stop by the One Fullerton, which is adjacent to the park, for some great dining and entertainment experience.

The Merlion is one of the top tourist attractions in Singapore. It is a huge statute of a half-lion, half-fish, that spouts tons of water out of its mouth constantly. It is slightly tacky but a must-see. The surrounding park is nice, and the best part is the view of the bay and marina and the overwhelming and futuristic Marina Bay Sands across the bay, which consists of three very tall buildings all the same height with a huge boat filled with trees on the top. Now that was an awesome sight!

A place which shows what SIN is, its a place where u can feel he aura of being in such a nice country conted among the best in the world! It looks as if evry1 is crazy to capture photos..but I tell u that I had a group trip and I had started from The Singapore Flyer..and was absolutely excited to see the surroundings! Hats off to Singapore!

review_title: A (smaller than you imagine) icon of Singapore
review_content: A visit to the Merlion, the icon of Singapore, needs to be included on the itinerary of any trip. It is busy around-the-clock, though early in the morning (about 8-ish onwards) the venue can be quite clogged with tour groups. If you go in the middle of the day, perhaps pop to the Asian Civilisation Museum afterwards to cool down, or take the Elizabeth Walk across the bay, rather than the bridge, where you will be very exposed to the sun. Fantastic views of Singapore, Marina Bay Sands, the city and Theatres on the Bay to be had, in addition to that perfect pic with the Merlion as well.

From the Raffles station, we looked for the Merlion using my iphone maps & a lil help from locals although it was'nt too hard to find. We looked for the One Fullerton hotel knowing that the Merlion is just behind it.  Any first time visit to Singapore will not be complete without a photo with the great Merlion, and so we made sure we will not miss this place. We went here early in the morning. People already crowded the place doing different styles as they pose for the camera.  Me & my siblings were careful not make any naughty poses with the Merlion so as not to offend anybody knowing that it is sacred to the locals.   I wish we had such a structure or monument too in the Philippines where tourists will automatically come for a picture simply because it's a must.

review_title: Great views of Marina Bay Sands
review_content: I love to come here and sit outside of The Coffee Bean and Tea Leaf and watch the Marina Bay Sands during the Wonder Full show in the evening. The Merlion is the symbol of Singapore and a must visit when you come here.
Its a great place to have a drink in the evening at the cafes near the monument... great photo opportunity and atmosphere...

review_title: Nice promenade to stroll along the Marina Bay, take photos of the famous Merlion
review_content: Singapore is usually sunny mixed an afternoon rain storm. Pleasant stroll along the promenade and you can grab a lunch or dinner facing the gorgeous Marina Bay and watch the Sands light show. The Merlion is definitely a highlight and fun to hang around with plenty of photo ops

I enjoyed visiting this, it is a Singapore must just for the photo opportunities. The Merlion Statue is cool but the overall park and area provides impressive view points of the city and the Marina Bay area.   If you are visiting Singapore for the first time, this should be in your top 5 things to do alongside the Flyer, Marina Bay Sands Sky Park or Sky Bar and a few others.   Lots of restaurants around also!

It's a good place to sit, grab a hotdog and enjoy Singapore view. You can see the Esplanade, Marina Bay Sands, the Floating Stadium and the Double Helix bridge from this park. It also has a row of restaurants and cafes.

The Merlion is the symbol of Singapore so its a must visit while in Singapore. It's free, and it's current (new) position has a great view of Marina Bay Sands across the bay. I went as a storm was rolling in so there weren't a lot of tourists - but it's worth the walk.

review_title: Nice view of Singapore by night
review_content: This place offer nice view of Singapore by night, there is a laser show at MBS at 8pm which can be viewed from here. Great Singapore icon.

Definitely agree with other reviewers that Merlion Park has been vastly improved in the last few years. All the construction in the immediate vicinity has added an air of sophistication but I do slightly miss the old carefree waterfront that was so family-friendly. And because this is Singapore where food is never far from our thoughts, several restaurants now vie for one's attention.  The Merlion, being the symbol of Singapore (there's another one on Sentosa Island), takes centre stage and probably appears in a million photos. It's not something I'm totally fond about - it's touristy, it's tacky...but it's got to be done.

Merlion is one of the most famous landmarks in Singapore and one's trip to Singapore is considered uncompleted if this place is not checked.   The place give a great view of the Marina bay on one side and the Industrial estate on the other side. The Merlion does look much bigger in real when compared to the photos.   Honestly, apart from few photo clicks there is nothing much to do at this place. But definitely worth a stop. Why miss posing before the Merlion and taking a snap for lifetime.

review_title: Nice Place to Sooth Your Tired Legs..!
review_content: It's like a park with a Merlion statue, but the Merlion is not as big as the one in Sentosa Island. There's a bench everywhere so it's a nice place to relax a bit before you continue your exploration of the city. There's an ice cream stall nearby, so go buy an ice cream, rest for a while and take a photo or two of you and the Merlion.  Downside: The place can be really crowded with people who wants to take photos.

The Merlion is so much bigger in real life. So many people must have had their photo taken here, and now we have as well. Cool. The history of the Merlion is interesting as well. Check it out. Singapore is such a great place

It is about a legend where Singapore got its name from. A prince in the ancient days founded Singapura. Singa means lion whereas Pura means city. So Singapore is a lion city. This is the reason why Singapore takes a lion as its mascot. The fish body implies that this lion survive by the sea.  If you are in Singapore, you must come here to take a photo with the Merlion status to prove that you have been here. It is an important landmark that you shouldn't miss.

According to my friends, if you won't visit the Merlion Park, it would mean your vsit to Singapore will never be complete. The Merlion Park has improved a lot since the last time I visited. I'll never get tired of walking around the area to see The Esplanade, The Fullerton Hotel, the Fullerton Bay, Marina Bay Sands, Singapore Flyer and the rest of the beautiful spots in Singapore.

Yes, this place is good for photos. The little lion is an interesting idea. Well done. It does help to increase the field of photography.  The merlion is great with the Singapore backdrop. Just need to take care of where the sun is to get the best photo. Happy snapping.

review_title: fantacy by night..boat ride by day
review_content: combination of lights and water fascinates me and maybe most travellers. at night merlion park is a must to visit.you will enjoy the lights and would be busy taking pictures.i would say this is singapore by night.in the it si best to ride the ducktour in the water and enjoy the bay view of singapore.

At the mouth of the Singapore river, the Merlion spews water into Marina Bay, and you will find yourself more willing than usual to jostle with the other sightseers to grab your pictures with—take your pick—the merlion, Marina Bay Sands, the Esplanade Theaters... a easy must-see for your trip to Singapore.

review_title: Visit at both day and night
review_content: We visited during the day and night time. Still pretty during the day but at night its much more. Its much easier to walk so much further in the cool of the night as well.
Merlion park is a good walk by night, with all the light show accross , through Marina Bay Sands and the Art and Science Museum
You may walk to there or take Singapore River Cruise. A must see scenery! The site is also very beautiful at night.

It's a must-be place when you visit Singapore. The Park is small but the city sights is very beautiful! It's a good place for taking pictures there. I think you should go there to see the merlion if you have enough time.

I really enjoyed the view. I think only an hour is enough to be here, then you can go to another place. There is a souvenir shop nearby, but it's cheaper to buy the gifts at the airport! I recommend you to buy vanilla ice milk at the Starbucks (very near to this place), have a sit, and think how blessed you are to enjoy this kind of places.

review_title: A place to sit, think and absorb
review_content: Take a bit of time to see Singapore´s tourists. ;- ) Nice place to be also after sundown, when the opera´s lights are turned on.

review_title: Just a photo op, but it's free... somewhat inconvenient to get to though
review_content: Walked here after getting off at Raffles MRT Station.  Nothing much to do or see here, except a a nice view of the Esplanade, Singapore Flyer and Marina Bay Sands.  Just get your pic taken here (to say you did it) then head off somewhere else.

If you go to singapore, you only need to visit it once for the picture. I went there at night, imo, looks better because of the lights. Also, try to see if the ice cream wafer peddler is there. Delicious bar of ice cream sandwiched between 2 wafers for just 1.50SGD
No trip to Singapore is complete without seeing the merlion, this is my 3rd trip and my 3rd time of visiting this iconic site, good views and pleasant area around the site
It has been standing there without any changes from so many years otherwise things change very fast in Singapore.

Despite the fact the Mrlion was being renovated while we visited it, we managed to enjoy the park, as the view from the deck is stunning - the Marina Bay Sands hotel, the Singapore Flyer and the Esplanade Theatres On The Bay. Other than providing a great photo-op, the park also helps to appreciate the amazing architecture achievements in Singapore. Highly recommended!

You can see a wonderful view ( Marina Bay Sands) and cityscape of Singapore. It is a place to kill all your memory card space.  There will have a 'water music dancing' show during night time opposite of Merlion. Enjoy yourself and you will like it.

Been there a few times. Scene seems to be good but nothing too great .. a lion vomitting out water. not all that great. But the statue seems to be good. I had been there during the day.. Not a great site.. Maybe i have not gone in the evening to check the beautiful view as displayed in the picture.. well I may be wrong.. Check it out yourself..
Lion with the tail of a mermaid. Thats where the name came. MER-LION. Best place for a photo shoot. Beautiful Place.
The show was superb. Really like the song "An Inspiring Journey" in celebration of 40th Merlion anniversary. The best view to enjoy Marina Bay Sands and Raffles Avenue from the bridge.

Your trip to Singapre will never be complete without a striking pose with this Half mermaid, half lion- the merlion, with the Marina Bay Sands Hotel in the background. This is just a few meters away from Esplanade mall.
It is quite crowed all the time there cause they all come for pictures. It is a good place to have coffee and a view tof Singapore skyline or beatiful buidings around.
As you sat on the stone and view, many beautiful building and sunset. All the lights came out brightly and marina shine in your eyes.

review_title: Check Whether Merlion is Still Being Renovated
review_content: It was with disappointed to see the Merlion, a Singapore icon, undergoing facelift in time for its upcoming anniversary. There is a smaller version of the Merlion nearby which is a poor consolation for the visitors. Around the area, there are restaurants and cafe which is a nice way to relax while still having a view of Singapore skyline.  The place is an oasis when it is not crowded. At night, it is even better as lights from the skyscrapers form a fabulous view.

review_title: Great view of the bay & CBD
review_content: Arriving at 8pm we were surprised with the laser light show and music over the bay from the Marina Bay Sands. We got lots of photos of the show including the lit up merlion. From here there are lots of eating places, and we also had a tuk tuk ride around the city. Lots of people were just sitting and having a picnic and enjoying the surroundings. You could also have boat rides around the bay from here.

review_title: it can be an ultimate chillax place!
review_content: Walk further down to the direction hotel. Sit and have coffee at starbucks. This is the best place to snap at Marina Bay Sands. With the breeze, water and view, it can be an ultimate chillax place!The Statue faces towards the River Bay and water is oozing out of its mouth.What a great spectacle.

Was disappointed to see that the Merlion plaza area was under construction and had deteriorated. When we visited it was lovely. Not much else to see and but it is the symbol of Singapore and luckily we saw nit as it should be with water pouring out of the mouth and river cruises coming up for photo's.

The Merlion was under renovation and although they put some panels around it, they were not successful in hiding the debris. Awful sight! Thankfully, there are a lot of other interesting things to see in this area.

Due to the addition of a new bigger road bridge in front of the old sight, the Merlion has been moved about 50 metres. The new sight was still under construction when we got there. Even so it is distinctly uninspiring, completely overwhelmed by the surrounding buildings, it looks pathetically small and insignificant. It's a little difficult to get there, and if there is any signage, I'm afraid we missed it.

Though the merlion was relocated to One Fullerton, The consistant exposure to the sea has made it so dirty and run down looking, pretty disappointing for a national emblem to be looking so run down and old....what are we trying to tell the tourist?

review_title: Merlion Park is still on renovation until September
review_content: Merlion Park is still on renovation until September, so if you want to visit just take river tour that located not far from the statue.

review_title: One to tick off the list
review_content: Everywhere you go in Singapore the Merlion is the Image used on their souvenirs.  There isnt much to do when you get there but it is a bit like the Empire State Building in New York or the Big Ben Tower in London, you have to go and see it. The park surrounding the MerLion is very clean and it is a short stroll form the nearest underground train station.  Worth a look but don't expect to be there hours!

Sadly the Merlion is on maintaince! For to see only the mini Merlion :( thought starbucks is a relief. The souvenir shop is quite expensive u must try china town or little India for great value souvenirs
If you are visiting and you don't have a picture with the Merlion, then its considered that you haven't visited Singapore! Its a must see. The beauty of Singapore is 360degree in this location.
Its a nice picture spot, but its gets old after about 10 min.
Please note that the Merlion at the Merlion park is under renovation for the next couple of months. Do check the website as to whether it is complete before you go.

Merlion park is the heart of Singapore. Most photographed and visited area of Singapore. Best place to watch Light & Lazer show in the evening. Nice place to walk, eat and relax. During the day time in summer, it gets very hot in Singapore so try not to go there. Best time to enjoy the beauty of Singapore from this place is in the evening. After dark you can watch pretty lights of Singapore skyline from here. Without a visit to this amazing place, your trip to Singapore will not be complete.

However, there is a small merlion to be photographed with and, of course, there are the views. Singapore's equivalent of The Little Mermaid. Much of the area around has been reclaimed from the sea which is factored into the development cost that your guide might quote. Do not let the renovation put you off visiting.
great view to take a foto and know history about merlion symbol of singpore. you can look marina bay from here

review_title: Meeting point of  Contemporary view and Colonial hub of Singapore
review_content: Great place to go to view the whole of Marina Bay at mouth of Singapore river. Beautiful walk on riverside past Merlion, colonial Fullerton Hotel, characterful bronze statues, Old Cavanagh Bridge and grassy park. Absolutely grab a fruit ice block from Frostbite, close to the Merlion statue: they are the best frozen treat we have ever tasted!

review_title: Nice area to visit, statue under renovation
review_content: The Marina Bay area is a nice place to visit. The Merlion statue is worth a look and a photo, but don't come only for this. Right now (July 2012) the big statue is boarded up and covered in scaffolding, undergoing some renovation work. There is an air conditioned gift shop to cool off very close by.

This place belongs to the great history book of Singapore. We began as a trading centre and this place and Clark quay area were the place where all the merchants atound the world brought their wares to trade. That's was also why the central business district is right beside it. Yes, and the Merlion has been here since about 40-50 years ago.
Nice statue representing Singapore, on a great location.
Don't bother going to see the Merlion as he is covered up getting ready for his 40th birthday in September.

Singapore's icon is Merlion (Mermaid with lion head). The most popular Merlion statue is located in the Marina bay area and adjacent to the Fularton hotel. This is a good place for you to pass a good time. Sitting at the pavement of the statue & wach the stunning view of Marina Bay Sands and the Singapore flyer is awsome. After dusk the view is more beautiful. You can also have a boat ride from here to see the view of Merlion.  Dont forget to take snap of this icon.

If you want to take stunning night pictures of singapore, this is the place. However, the connectivity from Merlion park to the other side is via regular road. It is sort of isolated from the other attractions

the view is great, good for taking photos. you can see the three towers of the marina bay sands hotel, the art and science center across the water. the area is also a great place to chill out and relax with starbucks and coffee bean and some local Singapore dishes sold nearby

review_title: Enjoying the view and watching the tourists
review_content: I agree with my colleague reviewers that you have been to Singapore when you can show a genuine photo of the Merlion. Besides that, I like to sit on the terrace of the Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf with a Black Forest Ice Blended Coffee to enjoy the view on Marina Bay and watch the throngs of tourists visit the Merlion. Some groups even unfold banners with names or slogans to go on the picture with the Merlion and the view of Marina Bay. This is one of my favorite spots in Singapore.

review_title: Souvenir shop a rip-off at Singapore's MerLion
review_content: Beware of the shop selling souveniers: I bought a T-shirt for SGD 24 there ("on special"), and found the exact T-shirt at numerous flea market later for SGD 12. My fellow traveller also nearly bought some other items there; and also found those exact items at numerous flea markets or shops later, for less than 1/2 the price. And the shop staff will tell you theirs is the only place you'll find that particular item; but you can find pretty much everything they sell much cheaper at many other places. Also quite a distance to walk from the Bus Stop (we were using the Hop On - Hop Off bus).
We tried to get photos, but because it is sucha tourist spot, there were not many places you could take a photo without someone standing right next to you to ruin the shot.

review_title: Well I guess go if you want a photo of the Merlion
review_content: its worth going once to get a picture of yourself with the iconic Merlion but otherwise not much to do here except go the good bars and restaurants nearby - of which the best restaurant is St Julien at the Fullerton Waterboat House.

Nice to see but nothing much to do here for young children/teens that they started to fret even before we reach the park itself because we walked 0.34km from the nearest MRT station at Raffles City to this place. We just took pictures and view surrounding landmarks like Fullerton hotel, Marina Sands, Esplenade and Singapore river, and left a few minutes later. It would probably be best to visit this at dusk until evening when sun is down and not too hot or to take the river cruise.

review_title: You say you've been to Singapore? What's the proof?
review_content: The very famous Singapore landmark everybody took photos with. You can say you've been to Singapore if you have your photo with this Merlion lol. It's beautifully located in One Fullerton Park; a clean park surrounded by skyscraper buildings and has the view to Marina Bay Sands. A must visit place!

This is a crowded but "must see" attraction. I don't generally like crowds but everyone was having fun and doing the same things, so I found it hard not to be swept up in the fun. There seem to be two photos that have to be taken while you're here. Both are similar to the photos many visitors to the leaning Tower of Piza take, showing (through a trick of depth and perspective) themselves holding the tower up.The first is a photo of you/your travelling companion trying to catch water from the Merlion's mouth. The second is of your/your travelling companion holding up the top platform of the nearby Marina Bay Sands. It's popular, very touristy and fun. I enjoyed it and would recommend it if you don't mind the crowds.
You haven't done Singapore if you don't stop here for a photo! Hordes of tourists but well worth a look.

A good and again super clean park.  I feel like I must visit this park as it become an icon for singapore.  But the problem for us is the facility for a 'Pram' way. Most of the place in singapore uses stairs, and difficult for me to find the way for strollers user or wheelchair users.  So it is not easy for us to get there.. most of the time we use stairs and carry the strollers (which is dangerous).
If spending only a few days in Singapore, this is a must... great scenery, I could just stare at the views for hours. Good restaurants and coffee hot spots, a definite must for tourist or locals

Who can really go to Singapore without taking the iconic photo? I must say I was actually expecting a park given the name but there is not a blade of grass to be seen. What there is is a crowd of shutterbugs trying the capture their special image for the statue. You need to do it but get in, take your photo and then walk around to Marina Bay Sands.

Go there by night and get a picture with the Marina Bay Sands hotel in the background. Then, have a walk around the river and enjoy this very modern, lively neighborhood where the towering skyscrapers surround you at all times with their multi coloured neon lightings! From there, you can easily walk to Clark Quay to have a drink or go clubbing.

review_title: A must see for people visiting Singapore
review_content: Merlion park is a top tourist destination where you can find the Singapore landmark, the merlion. There's some coffee shops and restaurants near the merlion for from food and drinks if you need them. From here you also get to see the Marina Bay Sands hotel/casino, Singapore Flyer, and Esplanade.   I strongly suggest going here at night. For one, it won't be as hot and humid as visiting it during the day. Second, the lights come out at night casting beautiful colored reflections on the water from the Marina Bay Sands, Singapore Flyer and Esplanade. Finally, at 9:30 PM, Marina Bay Sands has a light show that you can watch from across the water.

this is the most spot when we visit singapore, eveyone should take a picture to share with their friends to announce that "we've been in Singapore". :) and we can see the marina bay sand from the pierplank.

The merlion is one of those things you have to see on your tour. The whole area around is teeming with photos opportunities and restaurants. Also look out for the extra large Merlion on Sentosa island.
the last time i visited this place was as crowded as the time b4 last time i went! nth much to c except this statue...n with lotsa tourist

When you visit Singapore, I think you are complete your journey without seeing Merlion. it's one of the Singapore Icon. It's very plain and usual statue. But the value makes you feel that this mermaid and lion combination is the cool place to take picture with.  TIPS: Bring your Wide shoot and automatic camera in order not to loose the moment with this icon.

review_title: We spent a great day here.
review_content: Merlion “Park” as it’s referred to, is the focal point of the Marina Bay, and is a great place to start your exploration of the nice walks up and down the Singapore River to Boat Quay and Clarke Quay. If you tire of walking, you can always hop on a water taxi for part of the way. - Ladies, take a parasol for shade; they look nice on your pictures too!  Everyone takes pictures of the Merlion, the focal point of this area and the new symbol of Singapore, standing there on the edge of the bay, spouting a stream of water towards the Marina Bay Sands Hotel & Casino on the other side. If only this mythical beast had the ability to raise an extended middle finger towards this three-legged monstrosity across the bay, then the symbolism would be complete!  Besides the mandatory shots of the Merlion, you must take pictures of the magnificent city-scapes of gleaming glass high-rise towers of the financial district rising behind the even more beautiful Fullerton Hotel This hotel is equally as fine on the inside as it is on the outside – but my experiences here are for another day.
