For sure, Marina Bay is a tourist venue, but it is a nice place to spend time. I am a  “people watcher” and I take photographs, and there are subjects a-plenty here!  Another nice thing about it, unlike many places where tourists gather; there are no pesky vendors pushing unwanted goods on you as you try to force a path past them.  Mexico or South America anyone?

I admit I was excited to meet this icon! A Singapore trip wouldn't be complete without a visit to the Merlion Park. We were one of those tourists who lingered for a while to taking amusing photos of ourselves with the Merlion at the background. A nearby Caucasian tourist got us by surprise when she bent over backward and opened her mouth wide, as if to pretend on the photos that she was drinking straight from the mouth of the Merlion! Everyone around her was grinning.
You have to have your picture taken in front of the Merlion, but this is a great place to come at night to see the Marina Bay Sands Laser Show!

I like taking visitors to the Merlion - it feels like taking someone to visit the host at the party. Its a nice place for a few photos, wander around the river etc. If you have people visiting Singapore, take them down to see the Merlion - he loves visitors.

review_title: Its an attractive area, but there are better areas
review_content: It is worth the visit to see the Merlion the symbol of Singapore. The area has been extensivley altered in recent years with the barrage being built at the mouth of the river and the removal of the boats that used Clifford Pier. The Esplanade, Marina Bay Sands and the recently renovated and "recycled" buildings in the area are all close by.

Your visit to Singapore is not complete without visiting this cute landmark of Singapore. A national icon, for all that is worth for you to visit it. It seems like it is mandatory for you to take photo with the Merlion so that you can proudly say that you come back from Singapore in your respective country. But the main problem is it is over-crowded with tourists, especially on late evening. Besides that, from here you can take photo of the Central Business District , Marina Bay Sands, Marina Bay Promenade with elegant Esplanade.In conclusion, the merlion park doesn't offer much, apart from the merlion figure itself.

review_title: Beautiful scenery! Especially at night time.
review_content: Beautiful scenery! Especially at night time. Merlion is Singapore's signature/symbol, so, it is one of a must seen! :)
Good attraction. Take pics and enjoy the waterfront. Alot of tourist shops and the flyer is nearby.

Have already been to this place many times, it's always nice to just sit around or take a photo. Esplanade, The Merlion, Marina Bay Sands, all visible from this point. The place is quite interesting to take a panoramic photo. You might as well smell the stench of the sea in this place. If you want to follow the River Tour, one of the pick-up point is here.

We were there late afternoon and it was very hot and windy. We captured few nice shots of Sands casino and the Merlion flashing water. After our Esplanade visit, late in the evening we walk over again to Merlion on the way back to our hotel and the environment was different. With the lightings and cooler air the atmosphere was great. Cooling and beautiful.

review_title: Fantastic place to get a panaromic view of Marina Reservior, apart from the touristy legend.
review_content: This is a must-stop for all first-timers to Singapore. Apart from getting a photo with the perpetually-regurgitating national icon, it is also a great location to see the Esplanade, Marina Bay Sands and the CBD, both new and old. Interesting modern architecture too in the form of MBS and the Sail.   Access can be a bit tricky though if you are on foot and unguided. You will have to cross the multiple carriageway road from Fullerton hotel to get to the park. But no worries, drivers in Singapore do follow the traffic regulations and they will stop at the pedestrian crossing.   TIP: the road that you crossed forms part of the annual F1 Singapore Grand Prix and it's a notorious turn where spins do occur. It is not often one gets to walk on a Grand Prix track!

The Merlion Park is accessible easily by MRT.  get off at Raffles Place and walk towards fullerton hotel across the road and you are in merlion park in about 5 minutes time.This is an excellent place to spend an evening watching the marinabay hotel towering in the background and the tour boats passing by..This is become a sort of compulsory photo stop for a singapore tourist as you will find lots of them clicking from all angles. As darkness sets in the laser lighting of the merlion adds more zest to it.There are few eateries around to take care of the hunger and thirst pangs. Worth a visit.
view is better at night; merlion and surrounding view easier to capture on film at night.
No control, tourists everywhere, difficult to get good photo's. Govt should employ a crowd control, or maybe you can call them Service assistants, to allow everyone some view time.

You cannot go to Singapore without coming here. Across the water, there is the Marina Bay Sands and on your left is the Esplanade while the central business district is on the right. It's a good starting point if you want to take a walk around. When we went there on a Saturday afternoon there were a lot of people, and there was also a couple, all dressed up in wedding finery while having their prenup photos taken with the merlion as a backdrop. The symbolism of the Merlion just blew me away.

The merlion has been overtaken as Singapore's mascot by the tablet-like towers of Marina Bay Sands. A recent overhaul has left it looking cleaner. Good photo ops and nice bay views but not sure if its worth a trip specifically to see the water-vomiting lion-fish.
The scenery is very beautiful. I think that it portrays Singapore in a very positive way. :-) This building really brightens up my mood!

No visit to Singapore would be complete without a photo at the Merlion Park. Lots of people, though, but you shouldn't miss having your photo taken here. Excellent shots too of Marina Bay Sands and the Singapore Flyer.

review_title: must place to go in s'pore
review_content: if you come to s'pore , you must go to merlion ! nice place for take a photo

review_title: Stop and See the National Symbol of Singapore, the Merlion
review_content: Marina bay has developed nicely over the past few years, and there is now a great walking path all the way around the bay. Start at the Merlion Park and check out the fountain, a favorite photo spot with tourists. This used to be the beach and all the development across the bay was just water. The new development south of this point is on reclaimed land. Work your way counter clockwise around the bay, past Fullerton place, Customs House, the Central Promontory, along the boardwalk adjacent to the Sands, and then across the helix bridge. You can work your way along the waterfront, past the Floating Platform and ending up at the Marina Promenade and the Out-Door Theater by the Esplanade. There is always something happening, with art exhibits, light shows and free concerts and entertainment. Scenic and fun, and great for repeat visits!

review_title: Central gathering spot for tourists in Singapore
review_content: This seems to be the central area all tours run through, though that isn't necessarily a bad thing. The park gives you a great location to take many memorable & scenic photographs, including the Merlion statue, stadium on the water, or the Marina Sands Bay Hotel. Ice cream, Starbucks and a bar all nearby. Good place to people watch. I enjoyed watching everyone taking photos pretending the lion was spitting in their mouths.

While in Singapore, a visit to the Merlion Park is a must, more so for a photoshoot. I had been there with my wife and kids on 12th March 2012, not once but twice as the trips were overlapped due to a coincidence. The first visit was during the day and the next one was @ night. Take my word, if you have a choice go for the night trip. The landscape @ night looks brilliant and you and even see the Merlion changing its colors. The Fullerton hotel which forms the background adds to the scenic views which you will surely capture in your cameras. The sky scrapers on the opposite side of the bay and the beautiful Marina Bay Sands view will surely add up to the "likes" on Facebook when you upload the pictures. However if you are not a afficando of photography toucan give this trip a miss!

review_title: A national icon, for all that is worth
review_content: It's strange, in somewhere as serious-minded and well organised as Singapore, that the official national icon is a fictitious half-lion, half-fish, perpetually belching water into Marina Bay.  But so it is, and arguably this is the mandatory photo opportunity for every visitor to Singapore. I don't buy that; it suggests the pinnacle of any visit to Singapore is a ferro-concrete statue, when there are so many other things: the zoo, the omnipresent hawker centres, the malls, the museums, that are all more Singaporean than this.  But nobody had to be rational when on holiday, did they?  The only other point against Merlion Park is that it's not so much a park (somewhere restful to pause, with gardens, recreational facilities, etc) as a paved area with a statue in the middle. There are various restaurants and bars close by; still, don't mistake it for something you absolutely have to do. Your life may yet be complete without a picture of you in front of the Merlion.

If you are in Singapore either for a short visit or a long stay, its mandatory to see the Merlion! For years it has been Singapore's tourism icon. It has amazing views around the sunset, you can also catch a glimpse of the Merlion if you are taking the river cruse from Clark Quay.
Beautiful sight esp when the laser show comes on. Can see city line, merlion and MBS. Perfect fro photography. Many restaurants & cafe within walking distance.
The symbol of Singapore... nothing much to see, just the merlion....  good for picture taking... that's all...  You have to visit here if you visit Singapore, or else, you've never been to SG.

review_title: Need to make it more alive
review_content: It will be good if they could have a few stalls selling reasonably priced Merlion theme souvenirs. Or get Merlion mascots to go there & have their photos taken with tourists. Make it more fun baby! Singapore Tourism Board need not get so hung up about it. Give the tourists a break. Look at Osaka's Dohtonbori. It is buzzing with life.

review_title: Nice place to hang out at night
review_content: Great place to come at night. Do a stroll along the river from Clarke Quay and end up here with a cup of coffee or an ice cream
barely a spot that is not under the Sun. Only the tourists would go there.

Actually the best views are at night - turn around and see the Fullerton Building now and a scandalously expensive hotel lit up - really good pix here. Take a break at the Coffee Bean. Look out at the water and imagine the Passenger Liner lighters of 70 years ago with the mems!
the place is windy during the evening & night. good pictures can be captured when the merlion lights up.
Pff.. Best thing about this is that its free. Seen the thing now move on. Nothing much here.
Exquisite view of the Merlion and Marina Bay Sands area. Get your cameras ready!

If you love taking pictures, this is a must visit place. Though it's scorching hot, i endured the pain, for the sake of good memento. Nothing else to say.. just for pictures. Take one of the most famous pose, place yourself to make it looks like your drinking for the fountain coming out from the merlion's mouth.

review_title: Nice view but that's about it.
review_content: Nice view but that's about it. Restaurants about but pricey and eventually gets full with tourists. Good place to practise on your camera taking skills.

Go here for that all famous pic with the water spewing Merlion!! Great place for some great pics!! Also can get greT shots of the esplanade from here too!!.....restaurants and bars are a bit expensive around here but some lovely places to choose from!! All depend on your personal budget!! Can't come to this city without a Merlion pic so a must see place :)

It is cool, though it is probably only one of those things you see because you have too. I was interested in it but also by the walk along the Singapore River to get here. Walking past all the skyscrapers and restaurants in Boat Quay is fun as well as some of the buildings in the old colonial district. We did it both in daylight and at night to see both sides of it and the walk- great contrast
Despite the high number of visitors as it is xmas holidays, it is still comfortable. I recommend taking the bus but beware you need exact change.

You have to have your picture taken in front of the Merlion. It just has to be done. This picture is wrong. This is the Marina Bay Sands building, which is now complete and makes a nice backdrop for your Merlion photo.

review_title: Nice view of the Sands Hotel...
review_content: Go downtown and you will see this and you will get your picture taken in front of it and you will have experienced another piece of Singapore. 15 minutes later, move on.
Amazing architecture! Certainly different to our last visit 4 years ago. The lazer show is amazing.
Looks ok, nice location, good photo opportunity.  5 mins later...next...

review_title: Go just for views of the city centre
review_content: I am a local Singaporean and I must declare the the Merlion has no origins in Singapore except for a fictional one. No matter what others tell you.  It was adopted as a symbol for Singapore when I was young and I am not sure why. I guess it is probably because they wanted a symbol or logo to represent Singapore's tourism.   The statue itself is nothing spectacular but it is iconic as it is a symbol chosen for and represent Singapore. You only need to spend 30 seconds taking a picture.  However since developments had started into the Marina South and bay sector, you can take a great stroll with great views around the Singapore city reservoir from the Marina promontory, Marina Bay Sands casino, Esplanade waterfront and Esplanade bridge. The view is particularly peaceful and pretty at night, not to mention much cooler.  Along the same route, you will find eateries, shopping outlets (both underground and above ground), river taxis, duck tours, world tallest ferris wheel and many much more.   On New Year's Eve, people gathered around the same route to view fireworks, shot from a plantoon on the waters. The view with the backgroun landscape is beautiful and an eye candy for photo-taking lovers.

review_title: Merlion Park....still the place to go
review_content: The Merlion Park is the one iconic attraction which everyone needs to go to when they are visiting S'pore. It's a aesthetically, culturally and historically rich place. The Merlion is a mythical creature with the head of a lion and the body of a fish, used as a mascot of Singapore. Its name combines "mer" meaning the sea and "lion". The fish body represents Singapore's history hundreds of years ago as a nondescript fishing village when it was known as Temasek ("sea town" in Javanese), while the lion head represents Singapore's original name, Singapura, meaning "lion city", in local language. You can go there either by day or by night, and it'll be a lovely sight, especially with the city district in the background. For those who might be there in the evening, I suggest you go there just before 8.00pm or 9.30pm. That's when the sound and light show at Marina Bay Sands at the opposite bank starts. The Merlion Park offers prime viewing spot for this enchanting show.

In general, the merlion park doesn't offer much, apart from the merlion figure itself. Views from the park does include the marina bay sands hotel and casino, the Singapore flyer, theatres on the bay/esplanade, And more. Doesn't need much time reserved if you intend to visit the icon.

review_title: Nice, but in an area with little around it
review_content: Nice to see the symbol of Singapore and the views of the Marina Bay Sand, but little else around it to see.
A lovely park to walk around and the Merlion is an essential photo op when visiting Singapore. The views from the walkway are brilliant.

We had to walk a bit to get here, we managed to here just before sunset. Just sat there and relaxed a bit.  If you have time, take the River cruise, especially after sunset. You will catch a beautiful view of the city.   Dont forget your camera!

review_title: Great part of a walk around Marina Bay
review_content: Make sure you walk by the Merlion as you stroll around Marina Bay. Great views from the Merlion of The Sands, The Esplanade and more.
The view, with Marina Bay Sands at the backdrop was magnificent. The kids absolutely loved it. We stopped at Raffles Place and walked there. There are plenty to see along the way.

Worth a visit, enjoyed walking around the marina bay and seeing the sights of the Merlion, Fullerton hotel, esplanade and various bridges etc... great part of Singapore to spend a few hours exploring. Would recommend a river tour also!
You have to visit the Merlion if you're in SG and get your photo taken. We walked there at night after dinner. Very nice.
Nice view of Marina Bay Sands and the bay from there. Not a lot to do otherwise, but there are restaurants and bars with good views nearby.

I suggest you to visit this Merlion Park early in the morning or in the afternoon around 4pm. If we're there when the sun shine brightly, I guess you won't get a great photo here, backlight! Don't forget to take a walk around Merlion Park, below the bridge there's a coffee shop, and quite good location to take some photos. Go to Cavenagh Bridge near the Fullerton Hotel, great view and great location to take some photos, too! :D

review_title: Great location for pictures and eats
review_content: Great for those pictures of the CBD Skyline, the Singapore River, the Fullerton and the Esplanade. Good restaurants and lots of places to sit and walk.

I had very good experience here. You can spend here time without feeling any boredom. There are so many things to be seen here. There is a park nearby and there is a super market 24x7 also here. You can go at the top of Merlion and watch the surroundings.

review_title: Be early to good photo shot. Almost by yourself!
review_content: I went to before tour bus arrive. (before 0830). No many people to share Merlion. I had only 3 other people. Sit and look and took few photos. Lucky I had done 30 people show up 15minutes later.

review_title: Old Tourist Attraction for passing attention
review_content: After the taller and larger Merlion has been set up at Sentosa Island, the original Merlion is probably less attractive! It is worth passing attention as there is not much to see around other than the Merlion itself and view across the water. One amusing reason to consider visiting the Merlion is to be photographed below it with the person being photographed seeming to hold onto the water spewing out of the Merlion's mouth! This is a popular tourist pastime at the Merlion Park. There are restaurants and more restaurants as elsewhere at Singapore, in close vicinity of the park and thus one can combine the visit to this attraction with a meal. Wild Lions have not been known in this region in recent centuries and thus any information on how the country took its name after a lion, at the Merlion Park would have helped.

review_title: Not that big but still worth visiting
review_content: Somehow we found really difficult to find. Not sure why- perhaps because Merlion Park isn't actually very big. Its not as big as the merlion on Sentosa Island. I went here in the day time but have seen friends photos of it at night. Definitely visit merlion park at night as the lights in the city is beautiful to capture on camera

review_title: Very clean area and one will definitely enjoy the sceneries around.
review_content: I like everything I saw at Merlion Park. I like most the speedboat with 3 ladies hanging at its back, all dancing and smiling together.

Situated between the durian-shaped Esplanade theater complex and the historic Fullerton Hotel is this small park featuring the iconic merlion (part mermaid, part lion) statue, which is perhaps one of the most photographed images of Singapore. From the park, you can appreciate extraordinary views of the Esplande, the SIngapore Flyer, and the Marina Bay Sands complex, among other important sites of the city-state. Definitely worth a visit. Go in the late afternoon, take some photos, and then head over to the Fullerton's swank bar for cocktails.

Firstly, the merlion story isn't even real. It's a concocted load of rubbish aimed at distancing our history from the original founders the Srivijayans (who also founded Malaysia and Indonesia). The beast sighted by Sang Nila Utama was said to be a mythical lion (Singa), long extinct by his time, but remaining in ancient carvings in the throne rooms of Sigiriya (Sri Lanka). The lion had no fish tail whatsoever.  The park is located on the site of the sand bank Raffles supposedly stepped ashore. It's all covered by concrete now. Also, his statue is at the side of the Singapore River where he supposedly stepped ashore.  If you ask me, all hogwash and poppycock. I think it's better to keep history real, otherwise you risk losing the line between reality and fantasy.

As a visitor, this park is really a must-see and must-picture. No single moment this park was empty of visitors. I always have a a seat and sip coffee in the Coffee Bean while watching other visitors in their picture taking with the Merlion.

unlike other Country, this park is on a good location and surrounding area is also make this place a unique and momorable one. Worth to stroll in the evening or take picture for souvenir. Other than that, it 's not that fancy.

Not knowing what to expect in Singapore I read about Merlion Park so had to stop and see what it was about. Not only was the fountain worth the look but the view of Marina Bay Sands and the harbor area turned out to be a panorama of architectural gems. Also a great place to take a short boat ride.

This is compulsory place for first timer in Singapore and take a pic with Merlion background. no need to go there twice (well, you do if you bring different people to Singapore.lol)  Better place to see the merlion is from esplanades, like I did. I was not really at the Merlion park actually. From esplanades, you can see both Merlion and Marina Bay Sands. With appropriate camera (with good zoom) you could take 2 great pictures from one place. Kill two birds with one stone, isn't it?

I took more than 100 photos with Merlion, City View, Singapore Flyer, Double helix bridge, esplanade & Marina bay sands Wow what a place In the eve 9PM there was a Laser show from Marina Bay Sands which is not bad either,   A Must visit place
The view of the flyer and sands are excellent, especially for the night show.
If you are walking around the Marina area anyway, stop and get your pic taken.

The Merlion, the symbol of Singapore, is integral part of everything that is is associated with tourist. Souvenirs, tourist spots and Merlion Park is epitome of it.  The huge merlion with water fountain on the backdrop of Singapore skyscrapers is worth visiting in evening. The view of marina Bay Sands hotel from Merlion park is unobstructed.  It is better to use underpass to visit this park than crossing roads as they are very busy.
Was ok, one can not after all leave Singapore without the photo in front of the Merlion!

it's definitely a must visit when any tourist comes to Singapore, but it's basically just a little harbour where the Merlion statue is with where you can walk and hangout. it's a good place to chill but nothing exciting going on.

review_title: A bit of history in a small park
review_content: Merlion is the symbol of Singapore and one must visit the largest of them in this park. It is a small but very well maintained park. Excellent spot from where one can take good pictures of the water sprouting Merlion.  This place also offers good views of the Singapore sea face

Just about15 minutes walk from City Hall station. You will passed war memorial park and esplanade to get here. with good weather, you can enjoy cruise from here to marina. i enjoy my time here, and its near to esplanade, waterfront, marina and suntec.
You have to visit Merlion Park and see the symbol of Singapore and hear it's history.

You can get yourself clicked with the merlion and the Marina Baysands & the Hand Convention Centre in the Background... Mostly for clicking Touristy Pics (I was there types!!!). The area is very close to the business district of Raffles Place and hence easily accessible and also crowded. Luckily I went on a Sunday!! Tho if you wanna see the actual Merlion (Bigger) and even get inside it, that is on Sentosa Island...

Sentosa island is a fun place. The best attraction is the "songs of the sea" which is an exquisite presentation . The segweh ride was a new experience although you shud be a little careful while trying it out.
Well, it was a symbolic pattern we enjoyed the best in Singapore.
just a statue of Merlion, it's better at night. From this side can see " song of river" at 8:00 pm with laze light

The walk around the river at night is spectacular and don't forget your camera for the light show near the merlion that happens (I think every night) we were unaware of this and had to go back the next night!
The Merlion park has excellent view of Singapore flyer, Marina Bay sands and Singapore skyline. Best for night view

review_title: You've never been to Singapore unless you've seen it
review_content: Visit in the morning and never on a weekend. Avoid the crowd. Its usually concentrated at the Merlion statue. Walk further down to the direction of Fullerton bay hotel. Sit and have coffee at starbucks. This is the best place to snap at Marina Bay Sands. With the breeze, water and view, it can be an ultimate chillax place!
Nice, tourist attraction. Like everywhere in Singapore it is so clean and safe. Love this country!

The Merlion was invented a few decades ago to market Singapore. The park was built on reclaimed land, and is realy a bay front location for shops, entertainment and restaurants, but the park is still a fun place to go and watch the world walk through.
I don't know why, but this statue is really cool. Not much around the park, but definitely have to see it.

So you see the Merlion. After jostling for a prime spot amongst all the other tourists, a quick photo and that's all there is.  You do get a great view of the new Marina Bay Sands hotel across the water.

It is like a Disney World in a tropical country! a must visit whenever you are in Singapore. There is a lot to do here. Be sure to take your kids or else when they see the pics they will beg you to go.
You should visit the Merlion statue at night...much better
Well worth making the trip to snap a picture or five.

when u go to sg, dont forget to go to this place. we go there at night and love the place. you get to see the merlion, the esplanade from afar, the marina sands and fullerton hotel. my aunt told me the sight is also like vegas. after visiting we go to lau pa sat to eat dinner.
Take a camera and you can tick this of the list in ten minutes.
Good and even better from a little way away. Good photo from a distance. Enjoyed the walk getting there.
The statue is probably best viewed from the Marina Bay - get a boat from Clarke Quay or include the trip in one of the hop on / off tour buses.
Great spot for photo's of CBD, Marina Bay, Fullerton etc. There are some funky little cafe's tucked under the bridge
I went on an organised tour to Sentosa which included the Merlion Statue. I did not enjoy the tour although the trip across on the cable car was very nice.
Walk from the subway past the Symphony hall for a refreshing view of the river, Marina Bay, and Flyer
There is nowhere else you can find this statue except Singapore! Great location! Great view! Easy to find!
Walked there & was surprised we were expecting something much bigger than it is & didn't think it was worth all the hype

review_title: A brief look is all you need.
review_content: I'm told there are four Merlion statues altogether in Singapore. We only saw two, one on Sentosa which you can (pay to) climb up to the mouth, we didn't bother. The other on Marina bay which spouts a jet of water. Most tours will stop by it, not sure if it's really worth a special trip.

Yes, it is just a statue of a Merlion, but it's classic Singapore so you kind of have to go! There are plenty of coffee shops near by, and also really good views of the weird Marina Bay Sands and the "durian" concert hall.

During my city tour of Singapore in August'2011,I had visited the Merlion Statue in Merlion Park.The place is superb for spending 1-2 hours of quality time.Merlion,as they say, is the national insignia of Singapore.The Statue faces towards the River Bay and water is oozing out of its mouth.What a great spectacle.From the visitors stand one can have a look of the Singapore River and the view is really fantastic.Those who love a cruise in the River can do it as River cruise is available.The park has quite a few fast food joints.  An enjoyable place for outing.
This was on renovation or something. The sun was terrible and it was a long que to see the merlion up close, so I gave it a miss. Had to settle for the small one outside.
No Singapore visit is complete, if you havent been here! One Fullerton Road, tourist everywhere, this place is on all the postcodes - Cannot miss this one
A nice spot to come for a wander along the waterfront. The area is heavily developed - possibly even a little sterrile. But it's still a pleasing diversion.

Worth a 15 minute visit or a cup of coffee in one of the coffee shops overlooking the Merlion Statue. Nothing great but didn't want to miss it as it so over-hyped. There is a much bigger and better one in Sentosa.

review_title: One of the place not to miss in Singapore
review_content: Nice to have some time in Merlion Park at Fuller Road. It is different from the Merlion of Sentosa Island because you can not climb on it.

It's a must-see in Singapore and is very historical - all the tourists get their photos taken there. The views of the bay and the surrounding area are gorgeous as well - there are several coffee shops nearby in case of rain and/or heat.
No need to see this creature up close-- it's not particularly attractive, and it's visible from many vantage points around the harbor. Why they chose it as a symbol of the city is beyond me...
An iconic symbol of Singapore! Don't go out of your way to visit but if you are in the area it's worth dropping by for a photo!
The Merlion is Singapore's iconic landmark.There is nothing much to do but click some snaps and get going.

review_title: Was closed for maintenance when we visited (Jan 2011)
review_content: We were in Singapore for a week in January 2011. Seeing the landmark merlion is a bit of a must do in Singapore, but when we went it was covered with scaffolding and screening as it was closed for maintenance and cleaning. On a positive note, though, there is a smaller merlion nearby, so we were still able to pose for the ubiquitous Singapore photos. The merlion at Clarke Quay was easy enough to find from a nearby MRT station. There is also a replica on Sentosa Island.

review_title: To show you are in Singapore
review_content: We took a short Bum Boat ride from Marina Bay Sand (only $4 per person) to Merlion Status. It's fun and interesting.

The Merlion is Singapore's icon so it is a must-go place for travellers who wish to take photos of their trip to this city state. IMHO the Merlion Park should not be a solo attraction in itself but as part of a cluster of attractions lining the Marina Bay promenade. On its own the Merlion Park can be 'done' in ten minutes. To make the trip to Merlion Park worthwhile, include other nearby attractions in an urban walking trail. Take the subway to Raffles Place MRT Station, walk towards 'Old Market' or 'Festival Market' or as the locals term it 'Lau Pasat' an alfresco food market which is immensely popular with the local office lunch crowd (avoid 12pm to 2pm lunch time peak), then head eastwards to the low rise Fullerton Bay Hotel to nurse a cold beer at its roof top bar, which boasts an excellent view of the surrounding skyscrapers plus Singapore's newest landmark, the Marina Bay Sands. Then head further east and you'll reach Merlion Park for your photo stop.  East of the Merlion Park is the Anderson Bridge which leads to the civic district where you'll find the statue of Singapore's founder Sir Stamford Raffles and Boat Quay if you use the pedestrian underpass. If you walk along the bayfront promenade, you'll notice the twin spiky structures resembling a pair of durians - the fragrant tropical fruit that one either likes or loathes - The Esplanade Theatres on The Bay, a very popular photo stop which is to Singapore what the Sydney Opera House is to Australia. Here is a good place to nurse another drink and tapas at Harry's Bar, South of the Esplanade Theatres, you'll be heading towards the Helix Bridge which leads to the Marina Bay Sands Skypark to round off your urban walking trail.

The Merloin status is one of the attractions of Singapore and probably the main attraction that people think of when they think of singapore. Because we were staying at Mandarin Oriental, it was walk away although when we went there, we came from MBS so just took the taxi.   The Taxi dropped us off at a taxi rank which is next to resturants. You simply walk down the side to the statue and take photos of it and admire it. Theres the big statue and the small status behind it.   We took photos and then once we took enough photos, we continued to our next destination and waited for our taxi. Overall the statue is a nice tourist destination for  tourists that haven't been to singapore. You don't stay long here and might only be there for 30 minutes max i would say.

Because my friends and I didn’t take a tour guide during our vacation in Singapore we lost our way and took us longer time in finding the Merlion Park from our hotel. If you don’t take a tour guide it is best to take a taxi instead of MRT in going to the Merlion Park as so to save time and effort. An obligatory picture of the famous landmark of Singapore is a must for visitors in Singapore. Thank goodness for cafes and restaurant lining around the Merlion we were able to enjoy the view, the Singapore marina at a distance.

review_title: This is just something you have to do when visiting Sinapore
review_content: We have been to Singapore many times. This time we walked to the Merlion Statue on the waterfront. but a previos time we took a Bum Boat ride around the harbour and i think that was much more interesting. Note that there is a much larger Merlion statue on Sentosa - where you can climb up to a viweing area in the mouth and the head.

review_title: Yawn. Just a small statue spitting water.
review_content: Sure, this is the symbol of Singapore, but one can't help juxtaposition the tall skyscrapers, bridges, and other impressive structures with this little "monument". The only place the Merlion Statue would look impressive is perhaps in somebody's front lawn.  Singapore should reconstruct the Merlion Statue perhaps a hundred times larger and more impressive, but then again, the current Merlion Statue attracts thousands of tourists as it is.

A small attraction, the Merlion which is Half Mermaid and Half Lion represents Singapore.   The Merlion Statue is location is what makes this attraction very attractive, the area around it is with high rise apartments and multinational corporation, u really are in the center of Singapore surrounded by its majestic skylines.

review_title: Good area for a walk, but this is a minor landmark
review_content: The marina is a good area to walk with family and friends. There are boat tours nearby. I think the merlion has been made into an "attraction" by the tourism business, because it is unremarkable and small. There isn't even any profound history, romantic decay, or interesting show, just a statue spitting water.

When we reached the water from the mouth of Merlion was not working, but still it was worth visit.   We completed G-Max Reverse Bungy and then we came walking around 15 minutes to Merlion Park, but the walk was more exciting as we passed some very well known building of Singapore, then the bridge linking to Fullerton was excellent for view and photography.   There were many people during our visit and we can get some very good views of Singapore like Marina Bay Sands Hotel, Esplanade, etc. It is a good place for photography.   It's worth walking and finding this place.

I went to visit the Merlion Statue and the squire in the morning and stayed till noon, get ready to take many photographs of you with the Merlion in the background. lot of tourists however area seems very clean and well maintained. accessible for taxi and nice view of the bay area. many restaurants coffee shops in the location.  There is a small statue and the large statue, which was under renovation when i visited. but not short of pictures, very good memento from the vacation and must visit place in Singapore.

There are 2 Merlion located along the lake front off the 1 Fullerton Road. It is the symbol of Singapore. The small one is with the fountain and the large one is facing the lake. We heard that the large one is the original statue. We are lucky on May29 that it just finished maintenance and the wood panels are taken off. You can up close and personal to the small one. The big one you can take pictures going around it for 360 degrees view. You can also see it across from Marina Bay Sands. If you are at Fullerton hotel, there is a tunnel lead you all the way to the Merlion Park. It worth a walk along the lakefront with a beautiful scenic view.  There is another huge one in Sentosa Island. When you going up the Sentosa hill, you will not miss it. There are a total of 5 Merlion in Singapore. I managed to see 3 of them. Statues that you must not miss in Singapore

We had an aabsolutely delightful walk near the Esplanade around the Marina Bay, and kept looking for the Merlion....all we saw was a small statue about 4 feet in height. We were thoroughly disappointed as we expected something bigger at least.

review_title: all I see is a big red box (bad timing)...
review_content: Conjure up images of the great city of Singapore and no doubt the icon Merlion will be in it. So here I was at the location on a pleasant April evening, as a tourist, only to see this National Monument covered in a red box-like construction with queues coming out of it. Yes I realised now it was just a 'temporary' artsy hotel room 'idea' and 'showcase' which, although was free during the day, I seriously think was a bad bad idea, and a joke to be honest. Especially not for a National Monument. This must have been made for people from the establishment across the harbour (with deep pockets) who have a fetish on spending a night(s) with a Merlion..... oh yes

review_title: A Singapore Symbol and nice views
review_content: For sure it worth a visit, it’ll not be only the statue but you’ll have some nice views of the city. Pretty cool spot for taking some pictures.

review_title: Do not hope to see big Merlion statue here...
review_content: ...or you'll end up feeling dissapointed. The statue is "under renovation" to be a hotel. What the @$2*&^&$$#... But if you're already there, just enjoy the beautiful view of Marina Bay, take a picture of Merlion's replica, or take a little walk to Esplanade :) Just enjoy your moments. If you want to see big Merlion, go to Sentosa Island.

review_title: Iconic Merlion Statue - presently being used as 1-room hotel display
review_content: The Marina Bay area is developing into what will likely be one of the world's best harbors for walking, dining and skyline views. Unfortunately, the Merlion Statue is presently being used as a pop-up 1 room hotel until mid May 2011. This means the top half of the famous statue is presently off limits to visitors, hoping to take picture next to Singapore's most famous icon.   This highly disappoints as this iconic Statue should be open for the world to see, not 1 visitor, per night, at a time. Fortunately for the Marina Bay and Fullerton road area, this display is supposed to be temporary and the Merlion Statue will be given back to the world visitors for viewing pleasure soon.
Only was able to see a 10 foot replica, since this landmark was under renovation.
The view is great, but the statue is smaller than expected, and there is a Merlion that is ten times bigger on Sentosa Island.

The Merlion Statue, despite being a major symbol of Singapore, is nothing to go out of your way for. Nevertheless, if you can, stop by to relax, enjoy the view of Marina Bay and downtown Singapore. If you plan on going to the Singapore flyer, the statue is not far and you can easily walk to it. This is also a great place take that special photo, to say you've really been to Singapore.

The view is OK, but this creature is hideous. Shame it was not reduced to rubble by lighting earlier on. This is a corporate logo and nothing else. Many more interestring views around Marina Bay . Rusty poles around, not user friendly

This is situated at a very picturesque spot by the quay. Behind it is a nice arcaded area of shops and restaurants. You can get yourself photographed here and get the Singapore flyer as a backdrop.   Nice place to spend the evening.

If time permits, stop by the Merlion statue. It has a great view of the marina. Ideal place to relax for a while. We did a little walk of our own from raffles place to Singapore flyer. We took a break at Merlion Statue. It was very good and relaxing

review_title: Icon to be seen - great views of the city
review_content: The Merlion is the symbol of Singapore. Visiting this sopt should be on your bucket list. There are great views of the city skyline from here.

You cant go to Singapore & not visit the Merlion specially because its the face of Singapore Tourism globally.  At the sametime its not the best attraction in Singapore & surely not a visual treat - just a good photo opportunity for memories!

review_title: Brilliant spot for viewing the Singapore Skyline
review_content: If you are walking around Clark Quay and the Singapore river area you are just a few steps from the Merlion, around the corner facing the harbour. Walk out on the jetty for a view of the towering skyscrapers behind the statue.
This is very famous place in Singapore. In all the singapore guides you will kind this merlion picture from whose mouth walling will be falling continuously. Nice place.

Its a really big fountain that spits water out of its mouth. I didn't actually go looking specifically for this, however walking along the river I saw a massive amount of people taking photos of it, and this in itself dragged me over to see what it was.  Its significant because it is the symbol of Singapore and it is in a great location. Especially beautiful at night-time when the backdrop to the merlion is the business district of Singapore with all the light up skyscrapers.  Also there is a few nice eateries and cafes close to the merlion.

This is a must-see attraction in Singapore. It is nothing more than a statue at the end of the river but the views of the city and river from the observation platform next to the statue are very good. It is also the icon of Singapore so you can't really say you've seen the city without seeing the famous Merlion statue.  It's situated at the mouth of the Singapore river and in a nice area with shops and restaurants within easy reach. If you take one of the city tours, especially the river tours, you will see the Merlion but it's worth returning to so you can get up close to it. It's a nice place to sit and relax too and just peopel watch or enjoy the scenery.  There's a small sister merlion next to it but I'm not sure what this is for. The one in my photos is the main one. There is also a merlion attraction on Sentosa Island, but once again the one at the mouth of the Singapore River is the one you need to see.

The Merlion is a major symbol for Singapore. Merlion Park protrudes into the river giving a good view of the area, plus the picture of the Merlion itself.   On Sentosa there is a further Merlion attraction. A lift takes you to the top of the statue to an observation deck with views out over port area of Singapore and the island itself. While the Merlion on Sentosa predates the Skytower and is lower, it has the advantage of allowing you to take your own time to view the sights.

The observation deck on top gives nice views of the city and the port. OK the little history film they show is hokey, and the exhibit on sea monsters is just silly, and they keep playing an annoying song, but what counts is the views, and on a nice day it is worth it. You can stay up as long as you want (and as a fan of observation decks I stay quite a while) which is why I choose this over the sky tower - it is up for a few minutes and then goes down.
Trademark of SG.The most popular park and very nice view.I wish i could come again to Singapore someday.
A half mermaid, half lion statue right by the Marina. It gets very popular so would recommend going early or late in the day.  A lot of people wait to get pictures with the statue.

No trip to Singapore is complete without viewing the Merlion. Set by the water with view across to the Gardens By the Bay this is a great stop for photographers. Image attached was actually taken from one of the bumboats that can be caught from Marina Bay Sands that gets you out onto the water for a different view point.

This is one of the must-see places in Singapore. Mainly for the pictures. But the place is super crowded. We went there at close to 6, and stayed till 8. At 8 or sometime later, there was an amazing light show covering the entire panoramic landscape in front of the merlion. That made the entire trip worthwhile. Not sure if this is a daily affair, so you may want to check before planning.
The place was so clean n the environment was so good.Me n my family enjoyed our holiday..Hope to come back again because this trip was a sudden plan so we cant go to many places in Singapore...
Neat little spot to get some iconic pictures of Singapore. Lots of tourists and not much cover from the sun. Quick walk away from our hotel past the Durrian buildings.
I always bring my visitors here. You get good pics of Marina Bay Sands and the Singapore Flyer from here. Also they love the ‘drinking from the Merlion’s mouth pics).

The Merlion Park at One Fullerton near the waterfront at Marina bay is famous for its Merlion statue, a half fish half lion statue which is regarded as a symbol of Singapore. It has a fountain of water spurting out from its mouth into the Marina Bay waters. I did not go by land but passed through it via a Singapore river cruise so avoided the crowd that is always there to pay their pilgrimage. Easier to capture a shot of it from various angles from the cruise boat too.

You cannot go to Singapore and not have your photo taken here. The views over the bay both day and night are wonderful. But I have to say Ioved it a night when the light show from the Marina Bay, could be seen.  Also its was good to get a slight spray during the heat.   Be warned it was packed due to the amount of tourist, but we found it got quieter around lunchtime and dinner. There are lots of places to eat and drink, but you will pay a higher price due to the view and location. But if you go just behind these hotels, who can get some great offers on food and 241 on drinks

This is the best known landmark of Singapore. And obviously, you have to get a picture clicked here to prove you've been to Singapore 😂  It's a nice place to spend your time and relax. There are cafe's and shacks nearby.   Summing up, it's picturesque.
It is one of the tourist destination to visit, as the park has restaurants and with the great view of Singapore iconic statue of Merlion and the best view of marina bay sands.
Nothing much to see but kids will like the area Good to hang around and relax a bit You should watch the laser show in the night  It’s beautiful 😍
When we got there, we thought the real merlion was a bit smaller than the one we had imagined. Apart from that, it was awesome.
We went at night to see the Merlion. The walk along the river is a beautiful experience. Glad we went to see it. It offers great views of the city and we got the best photos in Singapore.

Although this is an iconic statute of the merlion, it is nothing too special or unmissable. If you are in the area, it might worth dropping by to get a couple of photos or selfies with a nice backdrop of the river. Otherwise, there is just a bunch of overpriced restaurants and cafes nearby.

review_title: Photograph spot best for cityscape photography
review_content: In a day time this place will be full of tourists crowd to visit the symbol statue of Singapore. But in early morning and before sunset this place are good spot to take the cityscape photos. I meet many photographers that visit this place in the early morning and take lots time to get photos around Merlion, because this place are surround by the modern exterior buildings. So for the photograph and architecture lovers. You must come.
Your Singapore tour isn't complete without a visit to this park and a photo with the Merlion tower. Beautiful views over the river. Very relaxing places. spend time here. Enjoy

A tourist or a visitor of Singapore can’t say he’s been here if he doesn’t have a photo of the papa Merlion 😄😄😄, that’s what my guide said.   And it’s true, the Merlion Park is packed with all kinds of people from all walks of life, country or nationality.   You can walk along the Junille Bridge to cross where the unique building that has a top that looks like a durian, they call the Esplanade Theater. A lot to absorb and observe in this park 👏🏻👏🏻 it’s worth stopping by and stroll 🚶‍♀️ 🚶

Whooooo what is this place man.. this place really struck my mind and heart instantly the moment I reached this place.. such thing happened every rarely to me and m glad this happened with me and with this beautiful merlion park .. v went to this place in the evening post finishing our Singapore flyer experience and v took bus till here as v has Singapore pass which allows us to travel unlimited in MRT LRT AND BUS .. u pass through jubilee bridge which gives u a panoramic view of entries park including siting flyer, gardens by the bay, marina bay sands hotel and merlion park.. this park is very photogenic and gives u a very beautiful feeling genuinely.. it has something special.. post finishing jubilee bridge u reach to the lion head statue which is symbol of Singapore. It also has many corporate and financial offices too like many big bank offices in the surrounding along with some good cages and hotels nearby where u can chill and have beer .. it gets beautiful in the evening post sun sets it’s even more beautiful with the lights. In the evening they also have a light and sound show which I really don’t like much it was ok.. better version is super tree grove’s light and sound show it’s worth and beautiful too plus free.. both are free in a way but v liked super tree grove more..
Merlion Park is one of the best tourist attraction in Singapore , it's like you find your peace when you visited here. It is also an IG perfect location if you are an IG artist or even a blogger

It’s funny how people pronounce Merlion as Mer-Li-an ... this is just a photo spot next to One Fullerton and it’s really not the kind of park with trees and plants. It’s just a nice spot and restaurants by the bay.

The Merlion park has two Merlion statues: the big 8.6 m Merlion statue (that everyone wants to take picture with) and the small 2 m cub statue (that is mostly ignored by tourists). None the less the Merlion statue is the icon and symbol of Singapore. This is the place where all the tourists seem to flock to take pictures and selfies.  The place is the best spot to get pictures of the iconic Marina bay Sands and Singapore Skyline. The park is also the perfect spot to just sit down at the steps and enjoy the laser and spectra water show in the evening.

review_title: Must visit place if you are in Singapore
review_content: Now I was in Singapore for a good seven days, and out of 7 days I visited this place at least three times, I was in love with the location. I will keep it crisp and short, if you are with your partner or family then visit around 6 PM and stay till the time you want. The place is full of some excellent dining restaurant with a beautiful view of Marina Bay Sands. Of course the area is trendy amongst the tourists so expect a good crowd, but still, you will find your personal space for sure. Don't miss the sound & light show with laser lights. The show lasts for 10-15 minutes and is showcased at 8 PM and another one at 9:30 PM. Enjoy the dinner and just walk around the bay area till Marina Bay Sands and If you want to Photograph (for serious photographers only) the beauty of Marina Bay Sands then won't recommend you evening because of the crowd. Shoot it in the morning, if you can manage early morning before sunrise then let me tell you in case the weather is ok you may encounter one of the best sunrises you might have ever seen from a photography point of view.

review_title: The Merlion Park - Face of Lion, Body of a Fish!
review_content: Who has not seen this iconic place, whether in person or in media, the world famous and most recognisable and prominent face of Singapore, known as its mascot - The Merlion – a large sculpted statue with a lion’s face and with a body of a fish – spouting a long jet-stream of water from its mouth.   The place is known as The Merlion Park and is quite popular among the visitors; in fact, visit to Singapore is incomplete without posing for a picture with the Merlion in the background. Tourist throng to this park and get themselves clicked, especially in trick poses, from the viewing deck in front of the statue – it appears in the picture as if the spouted water is falling straight into one’s open mouth.   We too had clicked many such happy pictures, tricked ones and otherwise, with Merlion, and also with three-towered Marina Bay Sands Hotel and the cityscape in the background. The park also offers boat-ride over the Singapore river and also houses several high-end restaurants and eateries to dine-in.   Anil Bisht anilbisht@rediffmail.com
Not a bad way to spend an hour or two. We walked over from our hotel to get a sense of the whole experience. I enjoyed it far better than my partner so I might not be for everyone.
One of Singapore icon. A must place to go for tourist. Bring along your camera, as there will be lots of pictures to be taken.
Very touristy and busy but beautiful at night with the laser light show from Marina Bay Sands. Lovely walk from there up the river to Boat Quay and Clark Quay.

Hope you catch this place not under maintenance. Hahaha. You needed to see this to be if you want a leisurely walk. There are many restaurants and bars around here since there are tons of high end hotels around. We got ice cream while strolling aroung the park.   I've been photographer for many people here, not the pro but those people who says "can you take a picture of us?". So many tourists dropby here but I am to see them happy especially the families. I'll be sure to go here with my own family 😍

review_title: Must-see and iconic, but too crowded
review_content: You should expect a lot of people/other tourists if you plan to see the Merlion. It will also be difficult to queue up for good spots to take photos.   The restaurants around offer expensive food and drinks. You might as well bring your own snacks if you plan to stay a bit longer to wait for the sunset.

review_title: One Of The Most Photographed Place In Singapore
review_content: This is not an understatement or overstatement. Every day, you can see scores of visitors flocking this iconic monument to take pictures, selfies and also wefies. It is a must photograph place in Singapore. It's clean, beautiful and very well managed. There are lots of nice restaurants and coffee shops where you can stop by and enjoy.

It’s a must visit 👆🏻landmark 📍whenever travelling to Singapore 🇸🇬  Hmm…Why named as Merlion🦁❓⁉ Reason being it’s a lion 🦁 with its mermaid 🧜‍♀️ alike body pillar. Always very crowded with its visitors 👭👬👫  Ohh ya…There are baby 👶🏻 Merlion🦁 & mummy 👵🏻 Merlion 🦁, so don’t forget to capture your selfie 🤳 , photo 📸, boomerang or video 📹🎥 with both ya 😆  Do enjoy her full travel blogging 👩🏻‍💻📝& more lifestyle sharing, blog link at profile ☺️🤗
Merlin park is very close to the waterfront and gives you a very good look across the bay. Plenty of restaurants and small shops. Close to financial district.
The Merlion overlooks the mighty Marina Bay Sands So Just look for that and you will find the Merlion opposite the river! There is also a Starbucks right near it to.

The half-lion, half-mermaid statue facing Marina Bay is something you must get a photograph of during your visit to Singapore. Iconic, spurting water and proudly standing in front of the grand Fullerton Hotel and Marina Bay Sands, there is always a large crowd of people taking snapshots of the area. Merlion Park is a short walk from the Central Business District and other major attractions.

review_title: Great location for the symbolic singapore icon
review_content: The half lion half fish structure which has become a symbol of Singapore is great. A lot of tourists are present whatever time of the day you go is a testament to its popularity.  Takes about 10-15 mins walk from the nearest MRT to reach the merlion.

review_title: Merlion - best to go Early Evening
review_content: We visited the Merlion park at 12 noon. The heat was too much for us. However there are really delicious natural mango and durian icy poles. These icy poles are expensive but well worth the price.   I’d recommend to visit in the early evening when the sun has set to enjoy the Merlion and lovely scenery at its best!
There’s have so many restaurants and looking to city 🌃 you have to take so many pictures there I recommend to visiting there!

The Merlion has a lot of historical importance to Singapore and as such has been set in a really nice place. Next to the bay is the perfect place for this beauty. But there is a problem. Singapore is always hot and as such you will not be able to enjoy the view unless you time it well. I suggest evening boat ride. Yellow light from the sun is perfect. The breeze will keep you cool. The boat ride will show you all the major attractions from the bay. Don’t forget to take a seat on the open boat. Sitting inside is no fun. Grab a cold one if you can. Will really help.

The Merlion Park is wonderful and well maintained. We went there for sunset views and light show at 8 pm. The Merlion is iconic for Singapore. The view areas are busy but manageable. The views were amazing. The light show from the Marina Bay Sands was wonderful.

Went here one very hot afternoon yet tourists were still swarming the place to take pictures with the majestic Merlion. The Merlion park is just a small area where the 2 Merlions are found. People stay by the trees to cool off while some food joints offer refreshing treats to visitors.

review_title: Merlion park is awesome place to visit
review_content: Very nicely maintained the famous merlion statue the icon of singapore. From childhood i have seen the photos of this place. Very satisfying to be there. A must place to visit.

The Merlion was one of our stops on our Friday night walk from The Fountain of wealth (Suntec City) to Fort Canning MRT station. We arrived at 20.00 just in time to see the Spectra light & water show across the water at Marina bay sands.
Great attraction with lots if tourists around . Nice place for a daily/evening walk with nice views of the marina. Grab an ice cream and just sit and enjoy :)

review_title: A must visit place in Singapore
review_content: one of the most popular landmark in Singapore. I prefer to visit and bring my tourist friends here after we tried eating local foods at makan sutra which is few meters away to Merlion park. Best time to visit is during night time where you can avpid the heat in the morning and can experience the magnificent light in Singapore.
Very busy day or night but worth seeing. Capture your fun photographs and superb people watching! You can walk all the way around the Marina and plenty photograph opportunities. Enjoy! ⭐️👌🇸🇬
Its a landmark of Singapore. So many people and the weather was hot but we managed to get some nice pics.
One of the most Iconic View in Singapore in front of Marina Bay Sands Hotel, 🖐 star for this amazing memorable place 💪🏻

review_title: Good to spend an evening there
review_content: A good place to go and enjoy the evening breez. The lisght of high rise buildings, the boat floating in the river, the marina bay hotel and the reflaction of the lights on the river water is just amazing. Donno about others but enjoyed the moment myself a lot.
one can't miss Merlion when in Singapore. A great sight all around. Go in the evening for the great view. Raffles place is the nearest MRT, from there is 600m walk towards fullerton hotel

review_title: It’s a stop , not a destination.
review_content: The Merlion, while cool to see, is not a destination. It’s one of several places around the bay for photo ops or bay viewing. There are restaurant near by and an an underpass to cross the road.
What is supposed to be? A giant tiger shrimp with a lion face? It looks like an object from a cinema set. The park is nothing special.

You got to visit the iconic Merlion when you are in singapore. I was there at midnight so managed to avoid all the usual crowd. I liked it in general, you get a really nice view of the city skyline and of the garden by bays including the famous marina hotel. I would say 30 mins max is more than sufficient. If you fancy you could find the fullerton hotel just opposite the road and walk down to clark quay which looked more happening at night. Its about 15 mins walk.
Nice place and quite green fresh parks , it has fabulous view over the marina , but still nothing to see rather than the lion statue !
Definately worth a visit even if it’s just for the photo , but the whole area is great to walk around 👍

review_title: Amazing sight of Merlion overlooking the river.
review_content: Good place to visit suitable for couples and families. Plenty food outlets and bars. Good vibe and interesting site.
Entrance is $12, you only get to take a pic in the lions mouth and head. I wouldn’t recommend it for the price paid.
Great image. I have seen this before but this time it was covered in scaffolding during some repair work.

The merlion is the symbol of Singapore. 'Mer' is the French word for 'sea'. It exists as well in words like 'mermaid' or 'merman'. But who is a lion from the sea? - Singapore itself! The name 'Singapore' comes from the Sanskrit 'singha': lion, and 'puri': town or city. Singapore is hence the lion city and, because it is surrounded by the sea, we can even talk of a 'merlion city'!
user_location: Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of the Congo

review_title: Picturesque Riverside Park with the Creature of Singapore
review_content: Very popular, and sometimes crowded park with a great view of Marina Bay. The symbol of Singapore stands proudly at the end of the park spewing water from its mouth. Worth a visit. Catch the river tour boat here.

The place looked really great!! It was very clean although there were a lot of tourists, and the statue was really nice. The only reason why I'm giving this a 4 is because it was overcrowded. We went there twice and it was the same situation. Just shows how good a place it is. Really worth a visit. 👍👍

Amazing crowd and atmosphere. Funny poses by visitors while taking photographs. One can clearly see Singapore Flyer and Marina Bay sands. Go during sun set to capture the life time moments and witness the laser/ light show at Marina Bay Sands. Take boat ride to spend time and walk down to Boat Quay for loving dinner (opt for river side sitting).
Lots of tourist here. Quite crowded as this is one of Singapore's iconic place. This place is also nice for a morning walk or a jog or even just for a stroll after all that hawker food 😉
It was a very good evening spent there with the vibe really amazing and had a very beautiful evening at the raffles bay

We first saw this impressive statue on the waterfront at when we were on the Singapore River Cruise.  The Merlion statue is of a mythical creature comprising of a lions head and the body of a fish. It stands 8.6 metres high and water gushes from its mouth into the River Singapore.  It is rather imposing along the waterfront and is visible from a far. We saw it from the Singapore Flyer and the Sands Sky Park.  We also saw the Merlion again when we visited Merlion Park on Sunday 20th October.  We were informed that the Merlion is used as a mascot and as a symbol of Singapore.  There are 2 Merlion statues in the park, there is the original large Merlion structure on the waterfront. Close by there is a smaller statue of a Merlion cub, it measures just 2 metres tall.   It can get rather busy with large numbers of visitors to this iconic landmark.

I walked from my hotel, Marina Bay Sands in 20 minutes over to Merlion Park. I was super busy with large tourist group, so I didn’t get to make too many snapshots, but it was awesome to be there! There’s a full 7-11 under the bridge, snack shops, restaurant, and a great souvenir shop under the bridge too!

Never leave Singapore without snapping a photo of the Merlion. There are no exact directions to the park, but a quick hint: once you see The Fullerton Hotel take its grand underpass to emerge on the One Fullerton Bay. A few steps left and you would see the huge Merlion spouting water, with a smaller version of the Merlion righ behind. Come here night and day to enjoy the scenic views of Marina Bay Sands!

Well planned by the town planners as the Merlion is part of the river walk which connects you to also the Fullerton Hotel/Gallery and with plenty of scenery for breathtaking photos.  Can talk endless but be there to enjoy.....
Beautiful scenery with a full bay view of Singapore. Lots of tourists, place must go when visit Singapore

The merlion on its own, may not be much, but add the surrounding backdrops and views, and it makes it a place not to be missed for a good photo opp.    Nice restaurants too. We visited the Pelican which had a delish menu and a nice ambience.
People be patient and capture good shots and you get very good food. There are many other events. Don't miss LUGE it's the best spend some time fruitfully in it you will enjoy a lot 👌👌😎

The place takes a while to explore. Many high rises and a cool looking statue. You can check out the light show at night which kicks off around 8pm and 9pm respectively from my understanding. Lasts about 15 minutes or so.

review_title: Nothing too serious, but quite photogenic.
review_content: Apparently the symbol of Singapore - half lion / half fish. The impressive 20 foot statue spouts water into the Singapore River, and is situated close to the very impressive Fullerton Hotel.  Nothing too serious, but quite photogenic, also rather fun watching some visitor keen to get that photo by standing beneath the Merlion with an open umbrella...........
This my second time visited merlion after 5years ago. Not only merlion u can see but surrounds there can enjoy and walk to see Marina Bay Sands.

review_title: Fun mini activity nice stroll and view of the water
review_content: Free and worth a visit for a quick picture nice walk along the water and some cafes and restaurants close by too.

review_title: 年末のマーライオンはスゴイ！
review_content: 今回は、カウントダウンをマンダリンオリエンタルシンガポールで過ごしました。マーライオンパークは、たくさんの観光客で満員です！普段のマーライオンは、ご案内の通り白ですが、年末のマーライオンは、いわゆるプロジェクションマッピング？で豪華にお化粧されています。前泊していたフラトンホテルもレインボーになっていました。  This 2017/2018 countdown, we stayed at the Mandarin Oriental Singapore. Very nice fireworks from the bay view room! The Merlion, usually white color as you know. Countdown Merlion is decorated by means of Projection mapping! Very beautiful!
Easy walk if you are staying downtown. Beautiful things to see along the way. Cute fountain, just lots of tourists at once taking pictures. We snuck it in at the end, not a must. But still enjoyed.

It was a very nice experience great view and plenty of vantage points , the status was originally on the other side of the road but removed piece by piece and rebuilt beautifully . There are toilets, it's wheel chair accessible and plenty of places to get a feed , a beer and even an ice cream .
Taking a photo with the Merlion is one of the top attractions in Singapore. A very scenic view to relax and enjoy :)
you missed the national symbol the elephant??/ then why did you go to singapore?? go alone not with a hop in/of group you will not enjoy the place

review_title: AMAZING boat ride a d Merlon view
review_content: It is the most amazing Boat ride that tell you history of the place and various buildings around the sea however the best was meelon view super attraction

The Merlion is the national symbol. The park in itself isn’t much to to. Walk around take in the views and get the mandatory photograph with the Merlion. 😊 It’s now forms and an absolutely must do photo on every tourist visitors checklist.

review_title: Great shot from the boat tour
review_content: If you do the harbour boat tour you go right up to the Merloin so you can take close up shots it is a lovely sight to see
This is one of the must see attraction in Singapore, and i would definitely recommend this place. You will get a very beautiful view of the whole bay from here.

review_title: Great scenery in the heart of Singapore
review_content: Great place for taking pictures and do some activities such as jogging. Strategically located nearby other tourist attractions. Singapore trademark.
This is a very lovely place to go to take pictures but can get very very crowded so sometimes hard to get that perfect picture.  Lots of bars and restaurants for food and drinks
Had a very nice day walking this area. Very beautiful and lots to do there. Plenty of places to get a bite to eat also.

Probably the main attraction of Singapore, then again, why not? The MerLion posses a great history and is a beauty of a sculpture. Don't visit Singapore and not make it to visit this attraction. You will not regret a selfie or two here. 👌

We spent a few hours wandering around the veiw is excellent and the water features are cool we had a great time just walking around great for families and the food at the kiosk is reasonable price not a absolute must see but pretty neat all the same

Walk along Esplanade and you will be able to find Merlion! Recommended to visit in the morning or evening as the weather is much more cooling and do check it out when you pass by at night too as there will be some nice lights along the way and you can see Marina Bay Sands from here! Good for family to take a walk for some sightseeing and get your camera ready and remember to "drink" the water from Merlion!

The Merlion Park is a must-see spot in Singapore! The famous Merlion is there, and one can get a great view of the three-building structure from this side of the bay! The Durian looking theatre is always within reach. It’s like one stone three birds kind of deal; one will check off some major sightseeing spots from here.  Do note that there is always a ton of tourists at the park. Try to come early if you can to avoid extreme crowd. Recommend time spent is between 30 minutes and 1 hour. One can always extend their stay in this area, going along the bay. It is such a nice walk! Bike renting option is also available. One can bike around the bay and city center if preferred!

review_title: Beautiful Stretch if Waterfront With Iconic Merlion
review_content: The Merlion is the emblem of Singapore and this monument makes for a great photo stop. It is a very pretty fountain on perhaps one of the most picturesque stretches of waterfrontbin the city. It has always thronged with people but don't let that put you off, it really is a very pleasant boardwalk. It is very close to the Gardens on the Bay and Marina Bay Sands as well as the stop for the Singapore Rover Boat Cruise.
Visit both in the day and in the evening. Always lively. few food options, can be more. Mostly walking.
merlion is lovely and at night it looks more lovely. the area around look fab and marina bay sand, singapore flyer , all can be seen and walking distance from merlion

This place is very beautiful. And yes its FREE. No tickets required.  Its a must visit if you want to just walk and click pictures and have a great time. I went during evening and it was lovely view. You need to have a picture with the merlion statue. Coming Singapore and no pic with that is a loss. You can have sea food there also japanese food available. No indian food. Must visit👍🏻👍🏻

Of cause, this is the landmark of Singapore. I would say, it's the must to come. Night time is nice, light display and beautiful laser shows. There are many restaurants around the bay. After enjoying the show you can walk around and find a good street food near by.

As this is an iconic statue of the country, it attracts both tourists and locals to take photographs there. It is impossible to take a shot with the Merlion without being photobombed so be mentally prepared. Some tourists will try to "catch" the spewing water into the mouth standing strategically with the photographer helping with the alignment.
A mascot and national personification of Singapore ..Having fun trying out various posed to bmtake with Merlion 😆

I have to be honest, I didn't get what all the fuss was about a statue of a lion spitting out water. Once I arrived it all made sense why people flock to this location. It is beautiful. The entire area has restaurants and bars right in the water. At night time, the place is even more spectacular. I highly recommend anyone going to Singapore stop by this place, especially at night.
Visit to Merlion Park was something different. This represented the culture and heritage of Singapore and its economic and social growth.

The Merlion with its lion head and fish body embodies Singapore's legend of a prince who came ashore in Singapore and saw a lion, the fish tail represents the early beginnings of the city as a fishing village. The legend just makes this place more magical. Beautiful area bustling with tourism. Very, very clean!
Definitely come here to take photos of the iconic Marina Bay Sands hotels. It's refreshing to feel some of the mist from Merlion Fountain!

review_title: A must visit to this landmark of singapore
review_content: This is the place which identifies you with the visit of the country.. So make sure you pay a visit. In the midst of all the awesome buildings, lake and the bridges, this park is an easy place to reach. And ten minutes walk from the nearest metro station. A good number of photographs is a must with the merlion in background. By the way, a bigger version of merlion awaits you at the santosa island..

review_title: A must see when in Singapore
review_content: i know I'm in Singapore when I've seen the Merlion. This visit I went to the park and saw it as close as I could get with all the tourists about. Worth very bit of the walk to get there. Beautiful walk along the river and past Fullerton Hotel.

Know what .. you get a feeling of deja vu when you reach here .. one stands still & takes in the whole view.. Backdrop of Marina Sands.. The setting ☀️.. then the twinkling lights.. & your best friends.. what more can one ask for..walking down the street.. too.. then eating & 🍹.. Too good to be true..

review_title: A must go place in Singapore
review_content: We started our walk from Clarke Quay. We enjoyed the view of the promenade. You can see Marina Bay Sands and take best picture of it from the Merlion. If you want to have a walk at the promenade, better start early in the morning before 9 or after 5 pm. It is really too exhausting to walk around the bay in a sunny day especially if you have young kids.

My husband, 2 year old and I walked here one evening to see the merlion. Well worth seeing and brought back memories of the little mermaid in Copenhagen. Well worth a visit as that area is very nice and bustling at night.
For sure you have to be there once if you are in Singapore for the first time, it is iconic place and you will surely like the view around it and a click makes sense here.
It's my first time on Singapore. And everything is so clean and i love clean place, i am just go there with my friends and everything is so funny ini here, i don't know why 😁😅😂😂
It is a nice tourist place with good background to click your pics with the merlion which brings prosperity to the land of Singapore

We were in Singapore for a day and decided we must come see the iconic Merlion so we asked to be dropped off at Merlion Park from the airport. It was a quick ride and there are a few vendors and shops along the waterfront. Definitely a good experience that you should see once, but once is enough.
Walking around Marina Bay was a nice night activity, and this park is very popular that all tourists normally go to.

picture perfect, need to stop in this area for your remembrance pictures. it's too humid so need to bring extra clothes for my baby, best time to visit at night time you'll see marina bay, singapore flyers etc.:)
It a landmark place which one can go and see for a few minutes just because you are in Singapore as that is a icon created which is the face of Singapore
A walk from Esplanade can take you there to Merlion Park. Its suitable for a brief stop over as there are too many people jostling there with each other for their views with the icon of Singapore.
Visit Merlion Park Esplanade at night to get a better view of the scenery. We went here on a Monday night and the park still got a crowd.

This is a tourist must see spot. What you see on tv or pics doesn't do justice. You must be there to see and experience the merlion. People gather around and such a festive atmosphere. No age difference all are kids at heart. Don't forget your selfie 🤳 stick 😊😅🤣

review_title: A fun stop along the walk on Marina Bay
review_content: We stopped here on our way to the marina bay boat ride. It's definitely worth the time and a good photo opportunity.

It is a fountain. It was in the middle of the day when we visited this place. It was hot, and there were a lot of people taking pictures in front of the Merlion fountain. It is beautiful, but I think I will enjoy it better if I went there late in the afternoon or the evening.

review_title: One thing you should not miss!
review_content: This place is very iconic and you should never skip this on your tour in Singapore! Take a lot of pictures and remember to buy some souvenirs!

review_title: Finally got to see the Merlion
